150548861.review:
My enjoyment of Momodora swung like a pendulum throughout my play.

Right off the bat it felt dated (which it is). I was soon taken in by the art and visual style. Then the map really started bugging me. Just as I was about to bail on the title I got an ability that made the game a bit more engaging. Then I finished the game in the most anticlimactic way possible and I have no interest in ever returning to this title.

The combat is boring (often devolving into button mashing). The MV abilities uninspired. Tight controls, good art, fitting score.

I wish I could give this a 'meh' rating but I can't, in good faith, recommend this title in the year 2023.

149329403.review:
This is one of the most infuriating, annoying games that I went out of my way to finish.
It's a short action metroidvania type game that sticks to the heart of 90s game design with pre-set save points that are easy to miss when exploring, there are plenty of instant-kill hazards, bosses can do very high damage, decisions you make can result in certain save points being destroyed or NPCs dying permanently, and getting anything other than the bad ending absolutely requires you to find an obscure room that is easy to miss, requires two late game items (one of which is missible), AND requires you to actually notice what changed even if you managed to figure out to use those items at the right time.

All of that is to say, trying to finish the game can be extremely taxing. Sometimes it feels outright unfair. But that unfairness seems to be to cover the game's otherwise short playtime.

If you know what you're getting into and what you just read sounds like something you can deal with, you might have a good time with this! If you have a short patience for that kind of game design, you can take a pass on this one.

Oh also the game has almost exclusively female character designs. No idea why, but that's cool. i think there's like 3 males in the entire thing.

Picked it up for $4 after waiting for a bit for a sale..and do not regret it. I didn't even plan on really hopping into it yet, but after 24 mins of play, I already fell like I got my $4 worth. (so yea, I don't have a lot of play yet, so take my review with a grain of salt if you are looking for longevity.)

It was really hard to put the game down once I started...I just kept promising to myself just to one more save point. Its not reinventing Metroidvanias, but it isn't pooping all over them at the same time. It is just a good solid fun game to play.

145885686.review: Years later and Momodora: RUtM is still one of my favorite metrodivanias. I'm glad the series returned to the style of II and refined it, though III is good in its own way. The gameplay, visuals, and music are all top notch. The difficulty is just right for me, though it might be a little on the hard side for some. It's also not overly long and doesn't overstay its welcome, which can sometimes be a problem in this genre. While the story isn't heavily focused on, it has some nice subtleties and good connections to previous games. It goes on sale for about $4 to $5 and it's more than worth it at that price range.

145696735.review:
(Time shown does not reflect time played - no internet, played ~8 hours).

A very good platformer/metroidvania. I think it could have done with a bit more dialogue or otherwise implicit theming, as I mostly just felt like I was going through motions in terms of story. However, the combat is very fun and reminiscent of bullet hells. It is also a bit short; I've got 100% map completion after a relatively short time, with many deaths. I don't think that takes away from it, but it is worth mentioning. Visually there is a lot of nice scenery, and the secrets are nice to find. I think the game would fit well with someone who already enjoys metroidvania styled games as a simple variant of it. I don't think the puzzles or story are heavy enough that I would recommend it to anyone looking for those things specifically. But it is definitely worth spending the time on.

145040274.review:
Fun, quick little game! 1-2 hours of gameplay, but very fun nonetheless!

Minor spoilers(ish) below!




I loved the game, even though it was only 1-2 hours long. The animation and style is amazing and adorable, and the characters are memorable and fun! There's two endings that are both very easy to unlock, and there's only one set of collectibles that are decently challenging to find, but also totally worth it without needing to be required!

The only real "complaint" I have is I was hoping to be able to save some of the NPCs, but you are unfortunately unable to save them all. It's not a bad thing, and it's a good lesson in that not everything the hero can protect, and it helps the world feel alive outside of your activities, I just feel bad for them!

All in all, 10/10 game, wish it were a tad longer! Good thing there's Momodora 1, 2, and 3 available, with 5 on the way!

143356816.review:
Agora que eu platinei, posso escrever o que penso sobre o jogo.
Conheci o jogo por alguém que acompanho no youtube. Foi muito bem recomendado e eu queria conhecer. Cheguei com altas expectativas e isso é sempre um erro.
Primeira vez que zerei foi no Normal com 7 horas e 40 minutos.
Segunda vez que zerei foi no Hard com 4 horas e 10 minutos.
Zerei mais algumas vezes no New Game+ do Normal pra ver o que acontecia e não existem grandes mudanças além de posicionamento de novos inimigos comuns e dano aumentado pra eles. Foi um bom treinamento pra dificuldade Insano que zerei com 2 horas e 48 minutos.

Pontos positivos:
Toda a produção de arte desse jogo é magnifica. Pixelart, cenários, músicas, efeitos sonoros e visuais ficaram incríveis. Quero destacar a música que toca na "terceira forma" da Rainha. Ela empolga muito.

Pontos negativos:
Quero deixar claro que não quero ser cruel e tudo aqui é a minha opinião como gamer com 35 anos de experiência.

 - Gameplay muito travada. Ao atacar a personagem se desloca quase um passo pra frente e isso me incomoda demais. Pra piorar acredito que é a protagonista com o menor alcance que eu já vi. Ela também fica presa em movimentos e isso faz a fluidez se perder.
Acho incrível que a speedrun esteja em 21 minutos na dificuldade Normal. As comunidades se puxam muito. 

 - História super básica e quase inexistente com personagens que mal se conectam ou simplesmente não adicionam. Existem algumas opções em diálogos mas não existem consequências. A motivação da protagonista é interessante, mas a vilã deixou a desejar.
A protagonista não fala e isso me incomoda desde RPG's antigos do Super Nintendo. É uma escolha que eu gostaria que fosse evitada apesar de entender pq ela existe.
Quero deixar um destaque super negativo pra parte inundada. Nem todo jogo precisa de esgotos ou mapas inundados e quando existe um mapa inundado é quase obrigatório que exista um sistema de fôlego que não há nesse jogo. A protagonista respira por magia eu acho. Toda aquela parte não fez sentido.
No geral eu me diverti muito com o jogo. Recomendo mesmo tendo me estressado bastante pois a dificuldade se baseia na protagonista ser super limitada. O completo oposto de Castlevania SotN onde o protagonista é forte demais e deixa o jogo no Easy mesmo usando o Luck Mode.

143238115.review:
Momodora RUTM es un muy buen juego, cuidado tanto en su apartado artístico como en el gameplay. El diseño del mapa está bien implementado, invitando al jugador a reexplorar los escenarios anteriores para avanzar con la historia o alcanzar objetos imposibles hasta obtener determinados objetos en ciertas partes del juego. 

La ambientación gótica-fantástica refleja de mejor manera la oscuridad y crueldad del reino de Karst, que se encuentra demacrado por el asecho de una poderosa y malvada maldición. En este aspecto mejora bastante con respecto a su predecesor, que bien podía estar muerto un personaje al lado tuyo y pero la música te hacía estar en un cumple con la edición deluxe de Piñón Fijo.

Las mecánicas que ofrece están bien pulidas permitiendo que puedas acabar el juego sin utilizar ningún objeto en especifico (conllevando esto un mayor reto a decir verdad) pero con un abanico de sinergias que bien armado puede llegar a facilitar los enfrentamientos con jefes. Además de incitar al perfeccionamiento de las mecánicas al estos soltarte objetos únicos si se los derrota sin recibir daño.

La historia es simple de entender pero se cuenta de manera orgánica mediante diálogos con los pocos habitantes cuerdos que quedan en el reino o los mismos jefes cuyo diseño es único y cuentan con personalidad propia cada uno de ellos. 

En conclusión, Momodora 4 es un solido 9/10 si lo que buscas es una aventura parecida a un souls-like o metroid-vania a lo HK. No tiene rodeos innecesarios, su apartado jugable y artístico está cuidado de manera tal que se nota el cariño que los desarrolladores tuvieron a la hora de crear el juego. Muy recomendado y una autentica ganga si se encuentra de rebaja.

141789174.review:
It's a game that appeals to male, female, whoever-you-identify-as fantasy: you can turn into a kitty and take a nap.

As far as metroidvanias go, this one is a bit smaller in scale than its contemporaries (my first playthrough took me around 7 hours), but that's not necessarily a bad thing! In a world where a lot of games tend to be bloated with side content this is a very nice refresher. 
That of course wouldn't mean much if the game didn't have substance. And Momodora delivers in abundance. The music and ambience is atmospheric, the visuals are charming and detailed, the combat is simple but nice, the secrets are plentiful the story and the world are interesting enough. Beware that in spite of the somewhat cutesy visuals the atmosphere of the game is very somber and often depressing. A much reviled comparison to Souls series is surprisingly apt here.

If you are in any way interested in metroidvanias, this is simply a quality specimen of the genre. If you are new, it servers as a nice introduction to the genre. Either way, for this price point it's very much worth to give it a try.

141701106.review: I'll cut straight to the point - this is one of my favorite souls-likes of all time. It's quite short, and borrows much from the established souls-like and metroidvania formula, but it's execution is S-tier. The bosses are challenging, the secrets are rewarding to find, and areas loop in on themselves in a way that makes exploration satisfying. Despite the familiarity of the gameplay, RUM didn't feel unoriginal to me, and this is because of the game's brilliant atmosphere and soundtrack. The world of RUM feels lived-in and ancient despite not featuring many NPC's and hardly any dialogue. The soundtrack is what sends this game to the stratosphere, however. This game has a boss theme that is worth the price of admission [b]ALONE[/b]. It's really that good! The plot here is scant, even for a souls-like, but by the end of the game, I had become extremely emotional, and the ending struck me in a way that I won't spoil. RUM is a world-class execution of a tried and true formula that won my heart with its unique style and atmosphere, and if you have any interest in this genre at all, you owe it to yourself to pick it up.

141620961.review:
[i]Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight[/i] is simply a gem and it quickly became one of our favorite games! I am not familiar with any other game from the series (which will be corrected soon) and even though this game is fourth in the [i]Momodora[/i] series (serves as a prequel) no prior knowledge of the events is required for full enjoyment!

The story is simple. Evil is spreading through the country and slowly corrupts everything. Kaho, a young priestess from the village of Lun, arrives in the city of Karst to seek an audience with the Queen. Unfortunately, right on the outskirts of the city, Kaho learns that meeting the Queen isn't going to be easy because the corruption is particularly heavy here and the way leading to her is sealed off. Without any other option than pursuing her goal, Kaho needs to navigate through the different city locations to collect four parts of the city crest that have the power to break the seal. The streets are, thanks to the evil in the air, far from safe though and Kaho needs to stay vigilant as many enemies are lurking around and one small mistake can doom her and with her the whole country.
Despite the ever-present evil taint the city isn't completely abandoned and Kaho can meet a few individuals who are searching for their loved ones, answers, protection or they are just simply trying to survive - not that everyone is going to be so lucky.

Kaho isn't defenseless against the monsters and as a priestess, she has skills both in archery and swordplay… with a slight detail that she uses a Leaf for it. Yep, you read it right. XD Oh, I love this picture…
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=905197703

Jokes aside, as you progress you collect items with active or passive powers that will make you stronger in the long run and that's always a good thing. After defeating a boss you obtain upgrades for your bow or new ability; when you do especially well and manage to surpass the boss without a hit you receive a sweet item, which you can't get any other way. You can find other items in secret places or buy them from the few sellers that are still in the city. You can equip only three active and two passive items though, but you are free to change them anytime you wish even in the middle of the fight, which can be pretty useful! Active items, like the healing bellflower, have only a limited quantity of uses but do not worry, every usable item gets restored to its full numbers at every checkpoint, like your health. ;)

Fighting in [i]Momodora[/i] is challenging, quick paced and extremely fun! The controls are responsive and don't hold you back. Except for one secret boss you have to fight them all and you need to learn their attack patterns well as a simple head-on tactic isn't enough for some of them even on lower difficulties! Every mistake you make gets quickly punished, but it doesn't turn into a frustrating chore. If you die you get transported to the last visited checkpoint, but nothing else, you keep your items and all money. As for the checkpoints, they are distributed across the map very reasonably and there are no too-long paths that you need to re-do in case you fail (except for the finale and that's because it's [b]the finale[/b]). I also like the way you can save - you pray at the bell to open a menu or you just hit the bell with your weapon and it saves, neat!

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2940448979

I love the pixel graphics of both characters and backgrounds. The music is also exceptional, especially during boss fights. All of it creates a great atmosphere and in some moments I had goosebumps and my heart ached (oh, the fight with [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d-LcULezhM0&pp=ygUPbW9tb2RvcmEgZmVubmVs]Pardoner Fennel[/url] felt almost like fighting the [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2m_j6Ziz3vQ&pp=ygUaaG9sbG93IGtuaWdodCBwdXJlIHZlc3NlbCA%3D]Pure Vessel[/url] in the [i]Hollow Knight[/i]). All of the characters are introduced only for a brief time, which is a shame on one hand as I would love to know more about them, but on the other hand, it works well thanks to the shorter length of the game.
Aside from fighting various enemies, you have to overcome many obstacles in the form of traps that kill you in just one hit. Platforming is done nicely with a few truly challenging stages. But overall I didn't feel like being punished by it (like in [i]Indivisible[/i]).
[i]Momodora[/i] isn't anyhow long and you can get to the end in a few hours, there are two endings and getting the true one will open New Game+! Achievements are there to push you further through the rabbit hole and test your masochist's limits, so beware. ^_^

So what I am trying to say here is that [i]Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight[/i] is an excellent game with beautiful visuals and music, great gameplay and atmospheric and memorable fights. And have I mentioned that you get to play as a cat? =^.^= I believe that if you are a fan of the Metroidvania genre you won't be disappointed!

139854826.review:
I’ve been on a 2D adventure/Metroidvania binge for a while and Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight, takes the crown out of around 10 games so far. It feels like a lost Super Nintendo or Sega Genesis classic with modern game design hallmarks. 

While I’ve ended up losing interest in most modern Metroidvanis because they lean too far into one extreme or another, Momo: RUM is like a majestically seasoned 2D throwback meal. Perfectly balanced in almost every area I can think of, which lets the core experience shine through. For example, there’s just the right amount of move sets, an excellent slice of platforming, and a perfect amount of traversing and map revisiting. Even the boss fights don’t overstay their welcome like a lot of modern games that have sipped from the Dark Souls well. 

Visually the game manages to be quite striking, despite its seeming simplicity. I’m not much of a pixel art or anime fan, but I love everything about the artwork here from the main character, Kaho’s, design and moves to the creatures she faces. You can tell what the hell you’re looking at 90% of the time, which is a plus in this genre. It’s dark and fun in only the way manga and anime can pull off as you’re beating weird monster women with a sacred leaf while jumping over tomatoes with clubs.

I will note the game could be perceived as being on the short side for this genre, but I’d argue because it doesn’t include a lot of the fluff geared towards wasting the player’s time that so many modern games do to appease audiences that demand such things.

When a game I looked forward to playing for so long finally came out, I set aside an entire day to binge play it start to finish. I even pre-ordered it, which I almost never do. But the game was a huge disappointment. Rather than a day of relaxation, it felt like the game/day would never end as I forced myself to play it due to the sunk cost fallacy.

The following day I bought this on a whim since it was on sale, figuring it at least couldn't be as bad as the game I just played. 

Well, without intending to, I wound up binge playing this game start to finish. It's smooth pixel animations, varied environments, simplistic yet precise map system, punishing yet fair combat, and haunting atmosphere all came together to become an experience I couldn't be pulled away from. Even after getting all upgrades and the true ending of the game, I still feel I'd enjoy replaying it start to finish again someday. It turned a disappointing weekend into a memorable one!

137695392.review:
TLDR; 6/10 played on Normal Difficulty

I played through this game in 2-3 sittings.  Unfortunately, the last sitting where I put about half of the time in was at least a year or more after the first sittings causing this review to not be my best as I only partially remember the early game.  Normal difficulty was totally fine. I'm no Metroidvania/Dark souls pro, and I found the difficulty totally reasonable especially considering I finished the last third of the bosses after a year break and having to relearn the controls. The art is incredible, and is easily the best/most impressive part of this game. I love pixel art, and they did a wonderful job.  Controls were tight/responsive and I felt that if I got hit or missed a platform that it was definitely my fault. Story existed but I didn't pay much attention to it. Sound and music was fine, I just don't remember any of it standing out in a good or bad way. What causes me to give this a 6/10(ie worth playing but has issues or worth playing if you really like the genre) is mainly that every part between the bosses looked amazing but felt just meh to play. Trash mobs were trivial to deal with at all times and the platforming was easy. Backtracking was unendingly painful. Even when you can warp it doesn't show you which bell you are going to you just have to guess/remember which name goes where, which is such a simple QOL addition. I have no clue why they didn't add it. One thing I always look for in a good metriodvania is how much tension I have between checkpoints especially if I have got a bunch of new stuff. Is it worth backtracking to make sure I keep my stuff and not have to redo it all or push on and hopefully make it... And sadly that tension never really existed.

Overall, the game was a fun romp through a really nice looking world, but the zones/enemies just weren't  memorable enough to elevate this to a great game. Bosses were solid for the most part and while I enjoyed the experience it didn't leave a lasting effect on me. If you like Metroidvania's def worth picking up for a weekend of fun, especially if it is on sale.

136669003.review:
[h1]Momodora is a great game, but make sure you go in with the right expectations[/h1]

[i]TL;DR Good, but short and difficult. Buy if screenshots/gameplay look appealing.[/i]

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Amazing art, sound, and animation.
[*]Emotional story. The story is very minimalistic, reminiscent of Dark Souls, but less cryptic. There is a lack of hope amongst the NPCs, and at times, you will be forced to kill those who should be allies, not enemies. There are many bright and colorful areas, but also dark and moody ones, with splashes of blood strewn about. There is nothing morbid, but the games story and atmosphere often left me feeling uneasy.
[*]Good combat and movement. Metroidvanias are a mixed bag when it comes to their combat systems. Thankfully, "Momodora" contains good combat and movement. Pro tip, stay grounded and roll to dodge attacks. Jumping back after attacking will usually get you hit by tracking projectiles.
[*]Frequent saves. This game does not waste your time with pointless boss runs and long treks across the map.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]The game is extremely short. I finished my first playthrough on Normal difficulty in 3.5 hours with 99% map completion, most collectibles, and the true ending.
[*]Replay value is limited. There are collectibles, achievements, hidden boss items, etc, but most of these things can be gotten with relative ease on the first playthrough, and the things you missed aren't worth writing home about.
[*]The game has a high skill floor, without the ceiling being much higher. I actually dropped this game the first time I played it years ago, because I was struggling to grasp the game. Coming back, it clicked, and I beat it in an evening without much effort. Thankfully, there are more difficulty settings, but overall, I thought the difficulty curve was much flatter than it should have been.
[*]Hitstun nullifies basic enemies. If you've played a game like "Devil May Cry," you may be familiar with juggling enemies. In DMC, you are often against many enemies, and juggling a single enemy only gets you so far in a fight. In "Momodora," you often face one enemy at a time, and can just spam the attack button, leaving the enemy in permanent hitstun until they die. Enemies die so fast, I'm not even sure why the game contains hitstun for enemies. While I'm glad fights aren't a chore, they can end up feeling cheesy with no alternative.
[*]Unable to mark the map. The reason I only explored 99% of the map and collected most of the collectibles, rather than all, is due to the fact that, as far as I am aware, you are entirely unable to mark the map. None of these collectibles really matter, and I did almost zero backtracking, but the player should have some ability to notate where they will need to return to, if the game does not do it for them.
[*]Must hold Ranged Attack Button to charge. The ranged attack is extremely powerful, and it would behoove you to hold this button literally the entire time you play. For this reason, it may be easier for players to use Keyboard controls, rather than a Controller. While Negative-Edge attacks (attack on key release, rather than press) are fine, it's a pain to dedicate a finger to holding a button down literally 100% of the time.
[/list]

[b]Mixed:[/b]
[list]
[*]Hitstop is extremely long. It honestly reminds me of Samurai Shodown. This took a bit to get used to, and eventually it felt natural.
[*]Anime aesthetic. I love anime as an art style, but I find the extreme perversion of 99% of anime distasteful. There is really only one enemy I can recall that I would consider perverted, and that was the giant blue lady with massive breasts. In fact, you spend the entire fight attacking her breasts to damage her, and she shows up multiple times within the game. I found this fight hilarious, so I didn't mind. The imps look like kids, so fighting them was a bit sad, but that fits with the overall mood of the game.
[/list]

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Overall, I would definitely recommend "Momodora" to any metroidvania enthusiast. If you looked at some gameplay or screenshots and thought the game looked fun, you will most likely enjoy the game. Just note that it is short and difficult.

135068034.review: One of my personal favorite indie metroidvania games you can buy. I've bought the digital Xbox, and PS4 version and 100% it on both platforms while also buying the physical version for Nintendo Switch because I adore this game so much. The game is roughly 4-6 hours long, and admittedly I do wish it was longer, but that tends to be my main complaint on most indie games. Not that the time detracts from the game in any way. Absolutely love the high bit pixel art style combined with this very atmospheric dark, and sorrowful setting the game has going for itself. The somber, melancholic music only further adds to this games atmosphere. Overall I find the game to be fair but challenging, and you're even rewarded with powerful items if you beat bosses without taking any hits. Additionally, I find the save mechanic very unique and enjoyable. You run up to hit a bell that saves the game, yet it has no load screen or wait time. I enjoy being able to hit the bell only to hear it's chime go off all the while I'm still running forward with no slow down to the game progress in any way. (Personally I wish more games had a fluid save system like Momodora.) At times the game goes on sale for dirt cheap (Like $3.99) on all platforms if you don't wish to pay full price. (Even then it's not a expensive game to begin with at $9.99.) Highly recommend this game to anyone, please give this game a shot!

133958949.review:
Pretty fun albeit short game. Combat feels responsive and movement  feels good. It doesn't have much depth however, though given the short playtime I didn't notice fatigue till my 2nd playthrough. Bosses are mostly fair, especially because initiating a combo chain and/or stun locking enemies typically prevents contact damage which encourages aggressive play. Several bosses have moments where they are invulnerable/off screen though typically you are dodging residual attacks, or using tprepping spells so it never feels needlessly long.

The aesthetic of the environments,npcs, and enemies are appealing with solid animation, though the actual structural design of the world is just fine. Most of the zone challenge (on a typical playthrough) comes from instant death spikes though they are often easy enough to avoid, and benches are pretty close together. 

Music is suitable, though nothing really stands out after I exit the game.

The worldbuilding and story are limited but there is just enough there to keep me engaged. 

Achievements are very manageable and easier than they appear( for example the no death achievement just means reload the save rather than hit the retry button). It's mostly fine because it was short,focused package but if the next game is any longer then a lot more needs to be done to maintain engagement.

133855090.review:
[h1]Nah For Me But Maybe "Yeah" For You[/h1]

Personally this isn't for me because I found it uninteresting and since I have a few health related issues with my hands, I found it physically hard to play, however, I'd recommend this to people who are new to the Metroidvania style platformer genre as it is a low skill based game.

[h1]Combat[/h1]

Combat takes centre stage here in Momodora it's a shame it feels lacking. Ultimately you either stunlock* the enemies by repetitively hitting them with a physical strike or shoot them from a distance. It got repetitive quickly for me because it seems every enemy is weak against both of the strategies i.e. stunlocking them or shooting from a distance (they'll never close the gap).

* To render (a character) unable to move or react by repeatedly hitting them and keeping them in a stunned state.

[h1]Good Stuff[/h1]

> The game is easy on the eye
> Music is fitting and nice (at least that I remember)
> Exploration is decent
> A good entry level game for players who are new to the Metroidvania style platformer genre

[h1]Last Thoughts[/h1]

I thought I'd keep this review short and simple displaying the positive and negative thoughts I had playing it. I feel like I've done this so yeah, I have nothing else to add.

132480196.review:
[h1]Completionist Review[/h1]

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
This review will look at the game through the lens of its Steam Achievements, and so is primarily targeted at those that strive for 100% completion, or otherwise enjoy achievement hunting. Are there any particular barriers of note, whether engaging challenge or boring grind? Are the achievements designed well enough to elevate the game-play experience? Or are some poorly designed enough that you'll be forced to choose between a miserable slog or stopping just shy of 100%? If this all sounds like pointless nonsense to you: you are probably objectively correct, and there's plenty of other reviews for you. For those of you that embrace the madness like me, I hope this will be helpful!

[h1]Review[/h1]
Achievements here are mostly what you would expect from a Metroidvania (collect / explore fully), and are further streamlined by the game being fairly small, and there being an easily-accessible item that will alert to most secrets / items in rooms.  That aside, there are two points worth noting.

[b]Multiple Play-throughs:[/b] At the very least, two play-throughs are required to get all achievements, as there is one for completing the game on the hardest difficulty, which only unlocks after beating the game once on hard.  More realistically, one would be looking at three, in order not to do a full clear for other achievements on a harder mode than necessary.  Fortunately, the game is short enough that this isn't particularly onerous.

[b]Skill Challenges:[/b] In addition to the aforementioned difficulty-linked achievement (which involves one-shot death from anything), there are a number of other challenge-linked achievements (never dying in a play-through, never killing non-boss enemies in a play-through).  I would say this is a good game to dip your toe in the water on these sorts of achievements, if you're uncertain, but definitely worth being aware of.

[h1]Feedback[/h1]
If the concept of this review was relevant to you -- whether it was helpful, or if it seemed like it could be helpful but ultimately wasn't -- feedback is very much welcomed!

132092779.review:
It's a very small and somewhat weird Metroidvania. While it basically only has 2 upgrades that affect traversal, after the second boss it becomes surprisingly open and non-linear, as by this point you can route the rest of the game whichever way you want. There's only two 3 arbitrary keys to progress, one is to open the the last area of the game, and one is really close to where you need to use it.

The game also has a plethora of items (all of which refill on save points, so no need to hoard it), most of them are useful and decimate Boss Battles if you know what you are doing. The number of items feels surprisingly similar to games Bayonetta, where good players are rewarded with ways to be better and faster.

As I said, the game is short, but it makes up for it in terms of replayability. It is probably one of the easiest Metroidvanias to pick up and replay due to its short length and how the game rewards good players with methods to save time. While the first playthrought is tough, the subsequent ones are a breeze, even on the insane difficulty as you become aclimated to how non nonsense the game actually is.

If you like Metroidvanias, then you'll definitely like Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight.

128576968.review:
Reverie Under the Moonlight is surprisingly concise experience that can be completed in a handful of sessions, but I wouldn't say that it's lacking in content. The environments and boss fights that are in the game are beautiful and have clearly been crafted with a lot of love, and the game manages to have a surprisingly wide array of different aesthetics and enemies packed into its runtime. The controls are tight, the animations and sound effects are crisp and smooth, and the enemies have well telegraphed attacks and movements.

Unlike most Metroidvania style games, it doesn't require that much backtracking which might make it more accessible to somebody who is usually turned off by that aspect of the genre. However, there is stuff hidden in every area of the game if you are curious enough to go back in explore, which has also made the game fairly replayable for me. The structure of the game reminds me of Megaman ZX, which was also a traditional side scroller adapted to the format of a metroidvania. Every time I play the game I find a new secret tucked away somewhere on the map. There is a shocking amount of detail and content packed into this game for those who care to look for it, and those who don't will still find a pleasantly challenging set of levels and boss fights that can be cleared without a huge time investment. 

A surprisingly solid triumph for a series that has otherwise flown under most people's radars. It might not blow anyone's mind or change the face of game design, but its consistent quality and atmosphere make it well worth the price of admission.

128461188.review:
I only previously played Momodora 3, but I surely can tell how Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight is called for a celebration of what made that game (as well as 2 other ones I haven't played) good. You would be able to tell (if you played those games) the developers incorporated and fleshed out the art style, mechanics, enemies, characters, and much more merging them to make a great product. This game is successful in that regard by being its entity, giving players a lot of lead ways to explore at their own pace to discover items, extra HP, bosses, currency, and upgrades, which is all the more satisfying when you found something new without looking up a guide. Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight is truly a tight Metroidvania game, compact with plenty of secrets, sometimes it can be addicting that you don't want to turn it off before you unlock a door after uncovering a key item to unlock or something. 

The savepoint is well distributed, and the boss is probably the fairest for a soul-like game, as long as you are committed to breaking down bad habits, as well as patient enough to exploit enemies' play patterns and expose some in-game mechanics to make life easier, like holding down charge attack before entering a different room to the clear the foes out.

Highly recommended for anyone interested in a coziness game with a subtle mature theme and maple colour contrastment. My only gripe with it is being stunlock when using the 'elevator', you'll know what I mean by that if you play this gem.

126954786.review:
tl;dr: Combat focused game with tedious, boring combat. 6/10

Tried getting into the game once a while ago, I got past the first area and dropped it. I picked it up again today, and after getting past the next two areas, i'm dropping it again. For a game that focuses heavily on combat over everything else, the combat is some of the most frustrating and tedious I have played. You get two attack options, a melee attack with no variation and a bow with no variation. No up or down swings, no aiming your bow, nothing but swing and shoot. I've played puzzle games with more combat options than this.  Even worse, enemy attack patterns are boring and samey, and bosses are huge damage sponges. Difficulty options change your HP and nothing else, and enemies on hard mode (and even normal mode too!) can sometimes kill you in one or two hits, EVEN IN THE FIRST AREA. The platforming is just as mediocre, and same goes for the map designs. So many dead ends with nothing in them! Why? I want to leave a note here about the story, but it seems to be nonexistent for the most part, even in reviews from people who finished the whole thing. All and all, I didn't hate the game. I could never hate it with those beautiful graphics, but it was so frustrating and boring that I couldn't be bothered to finish it despite how apparently short it is. From what I can tell in other reviews, none of this improves as the game goes on, and you get a whole one upgrade that gives you any new options in or out of combat. I want to like this game, but it just kinda sucks.

125479450.review: Momodora's a pretty quick and fun trip. The controls are decent, and hitboxes are pretty well defined. My run lasted a bit over 5 hours on normal, with most boss battles being forgiving enough not to require multiple attempts. (You can customize your active and passive skills, which really helps.) The only minor gripes I have is most NPC encounters don't seem to influence anything, and the story is bare bones. Tip-wise, I'd suggest saving often (backtrack as soon as you get an upgrade!). The map is pretty basic, but outside of missing vendor locations, and not showing where on the map fast travel locations go to, you can make do. I found myself running through maps avoiding enemies to get to the next save point, and then backtracking to discover secrets. If you want merchant upgrades, you can definitely grind so there's a lot of flexibility for different play styles. All in all, Momodora hits the right buttons for me and I'd recommend the experience.

My playtime at the time of writing is 92 hours, but believe me when I say I've played a bit longer than that. This game brings back fond memories of dungeon crawling on school computers when I finished my work. It should also be noted that, no, the game obviously does not take 92 hours to complete. If you're aiming to 100% the game, it takes me 13 hours at a relaxed pace. If I'm aiming for a fast completion, it takes me a little under 1 hour (the current any% wr is ~21 minutes). The game's relatively short completion time to my total playtime should be taken as an upside in showing just how replayable this game is.

If you're competent enough with video games I suggest you go right ahead and start your first playthrough with Hard difficulty as its completion will unlock [spoiler]the Insane difficulty (start with max 1hp, my playtime is due in part to this).[/spoiler] If you're unsure and generally have difficulty with games, Normal is a healthy choice. In my opinion Easy difficulty trivializes things too heavily to be enjoyable, but it can be very helpful in the course of completing two achievements in particular.

Momodora RUtM is arcadey and simple to get the hang of but has enough depth to keep you engaged over several playthroughs. This is a go-to of mine for some pick up and play action. Looking forward to the rdein's future projects.

124228281.review:
I'd like to give this a mixed review if possible but I don't  think that you can do that. 

Momodora RUTM isn't necessarily a bad game but it isn't that well made either. Definitely nowhere near as good as say hollow knight or dead cells. 

Let's start with what's good. The art style is nothing short of amazing. The pixel art is really nice and looks a lot better than most retro games IMO. The soundtrack is also really good, no complaints there either. And plus the game is cute as fuck. And there are cats. But that's about it. Honestly if you like the art style and music, you should probably still play the game, just temper your expectations when it comes to the gameplay, which is pretty poorly designed.

So let's start with a quick overview of the gameplay. It's a souls-lite, so you  have a dodge roll as well as enemies that telegraph their attacks. However there are a lot of design choices that just make this system not work. So.. you have a bow right? With unlimited ammo. That basically means that you can spam attack any melee enemy. And ranged enemy. And shooting them stuns them, so they can't attack you when you are shooting them. Which makes the melee leaf basically useless. 

The dodge roll feels clumsy and it's really hard to time it so that you avoid damage perfectly. Plus it's not like it's really that useful anyways. As mentioned, you can basically bow spam any enemy and get them in a stun lock, so well timed dodges are only needed for a handful of ranged attacks. And that's not helped by the fact that most enemies have fairly vague telegraphs so you don't always know exactly what they will do (especially with new enemies). Now I wouldn't call the combat incredibly frustrating since it isn't really that hard but it is a bit monotonous and has very little skill requirements or scaling. 

In addition to that, the game only saves at saves points, and these don't come that often. Get killed, lose all your progress. This can also happen after major events, such as killing bosses. Oh, and also accidentally stepping on a spike instantly kills you. Yeah. There are a few sorts of upgrades and abilities that you can get but really these don't change the game is a major way. There weren't as many hidden areas as I was hoping for and I did find exploration to be only mediocre compared to other metroidvanias. And I didn't find navigation as intuitive. It isn't bad but it's not as good as say hollow knight. 

The story was also a bit disappointing. So there is supposed to be some curse in this land. You come here as a priestess and need to cleanse the land of the curse. But there isn't really much information beyond that. Nothing on how the curse came. Who the queen is. Characters are fairly simple story-wise, usually with only a couple lines of dialogue each. No fancy backstory for any of them. 

All in all, whilst I would say that the gameplay was kind of botched and that there were a lot of poor design choices, it's not bad enough that the game is unplayable. I still think that it was enjoyable thanks to the art and music but don't expect a masterpiece.

124123038.review:
It's absolutely grim that a game with such nice visual design can have such mediocre gameplay and such player-loathing decisions.

I was initially excited, having just suffered through La Mulana 1 and 2's terrible controls, to learn that I had some modicum of air control. This kind of vaporized, however, when I learned that my sprite seemed five sizes too large for the levels I was navigating through. While you have decent control(a little bit of slippery momentum notwithstanding), the individual screens are never really sized in a way that let you play with it. You have the world's most anemic double jump, but considering that it's needed to make nine out of ten jumps in the first place, the point of it seems kind of lost. Likewise, I do love having a dodgeroll with I-frames, but since enemies take up 90% of the space on any given platform, dodgerolling away from them just means you'll eat a hit anyway since the dodgeroll will barely get you through them.

Combine this with the most basic enemies taking four or more hits from your melee attack to take out(and the less said about the ranged attack the better, it's insanely slow, does even less damage than the melee attack and you'll only ever want to bring it out for when an enemy is specifically positioned to punish your use of melee), and it just feels insanely clunky to play. Considering that your hits stun most enemies, too, if you can land that first hit, they're as good as dead from stunlocking anyway, so nothing is gained from making them take more hits to kill other than annoying the player. This is on normal difficulty, by the way.

The bosses are a bit more interesting, but that's really stretching "a bit" until it's creaking and close to breaking. They pop up more or less out of the blue, with no attached fanfare or lore or anything, just boom, here's a big health bar to whittle down as they repeat the same two attacks over and over.

Another point of annoyance is the way save points work. NOTHING is saved when you get lobbed back to one by a death. Not your collecting of powerups or anything, which means that it gets insanely tedious if there's a room that bops you a couple of times and it has some stuff along the way you want to grab.

There are absolutely better platformers with more responsive controls and more engaging gameplay out there to play, I can't imagine what would make anyone choose to play Momodora over those, unless it's because they start hyperventilating when they learn that one of the game's first bosses involves punching a giant monster lady in the breasts over and over.

I'm kind of glad that the game didn't start out better, because it feels greatly as though playing for longer might have been a case of The Author's Barely Disguised Fetish.

122083666.review:
Looks absolutely amazing, and I really want to play this game till the end, but it's incredibly frustrating to do so.

I've played many challenging games before, primarily plenty of roguelike titles, and these games were a fun kind of challenging. Each defeat was your own fault and your lacking skill, but it was tailored in such a way that you want to continue playing and become better.

Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight is not like that. Momodora ruthlessly punishes the player for a pixel difference between a successful or a failed dodge roll, and annoying enemies that make these poor game mechanic choices even more frustrating and unbearable to continue playing. Forget even trying out hard mode if you're an experienced player (normal mode is just as frustrating though), unless you want to spend hours just learning how to roll properly without dying in one hit in the first area.

Momodora works like this in all aspects. You die by poor development choices, not because you actually have anything in terms of skill to improve on. And to make the game even more frustrating: after every death, you get teleported all the way back to your last save point. This makes for boring and tedious walks (and many failed dodge rolls) back to where you once were before you can finally continue the game (and walk back again because you died on your way there).

You cannot call these mistakes a feature of being a challenging game. An essential mechanic such as dodge rolls in games like these should work to help the player, not make the game more difficult to play.

There are mountains of other difficult games more worth your time. Do not buy this game.
... Unless you're a hardcore masochist and like being unfairly punished.

121319412.review:
[h1]At-A-Glance:[/h1]
[b]Game type:[/b] Action-adventure
[b]Genre(s):[/b] Metroidvania, platformer
[b]Art:[/b] 16-bit adjacent pixel art with some 3D modeling effects
[b]Length:[/b] 4-5 hours for a single playthrough
[b]Pace:[/b] Medium-paced
[b]Tags:[/b] Story-rich, cute, all-women cast, great art
[b]Computer requirements:[/b] Very low-end


[h1]Notes:[/h1]
[olist]
[*] This is actually the fourth entry in the [i]Momodora[/i] series, though you don't need to play any of the previous entries to get/enjoy the storyline here.
[*] Absolutely cute as hell action-adventure platformer with some Metroidvania elements. Mind you, the Metroidvania parts aren't [i]huge[/i], but there is an emphasis on ability upgrades and changes. No RPG leveling mechanics, but plenty of health upgrades and damage modifiers as you progress.
[*] You can [spoiler]be a kitty cat![/spoiler]. Hell yeah! And you only [i]have[/i] to do it once, but later on you can use that particular mechanic to explore all kinds of things going forward. Love it, it is a dang charming addition to this page.
[*] Having a gag-boob boss fight not once but twice is kind of obnoxious. But it's the only disappointment - the [spoiler]Pardoner Fennel[/spoiler] fight gave me the "oh yeah I totally get this game now" feeling that good boss designs should have. Took me over ten tries, but when I beat her it was basically a no-hit fight.
[*] This is a pretty short game as far as action-adventure/Metroidvanias go, yet it feels [i]complete[/i] in that experience. I'd rather have a short 4-5 hour games that gives a complete package than this be double the length with obvious padding.
[*] Soundtrack and art design are totally on point here. Looking forward to what the next entry will bring, which as of mid-2021 is under development.
[/olist]

120436602.review:
Little metroidvania that plays very close to a classic Castlevania game. Instead of just relying on upgrades, you have to solve certain puzzles / npc quests to advance .

The gameplay is simple, platforming coupled with a dodge button plus a 3 combo attack and a ranged attack (which can be charged). But it is really polished. You can also equip different accesories to help you in your journey.

There are plenty of checkpoints during the game, also usually before the bosses (which are nice, but not incredible). The map is not big as this is a 6-10h game, but even so there is a warp ability later in the game.

The best thing about the game is the tight gameplay and the art. Each zone is really beautiful. I also like that it is a short experience but really well done.

It is a bit hard, but not too much - most boss fights are on the easy side and you might even kill some of them on the first try. The platforming (it includes a few instakill spikes) and figuring out what to do are a bit more hard.

As it is a cheap game, short and really well polished, I recommend it to any metroidvania fan.

118491539.review:
TL;DR: Game is good and has good art, combat, music and more. Greatly recommended. Don't recommend you rush through it though, at least not on a first play through.
.
After beating the game once, I really don't need another play through to know that this game is really good. The characters, backgrounds, and enemies all look fantastic. The animations are even better as they bring so much to life. The game is rather short, I'd say roughly 4-5 hours if you're going for everything you possibly could get on your first play through. The game has no shortage of challenge and will regularly test your mettle with some boss fights.
Although with the secrets to be found and short notice tells on some enemies and most bosses, I strongly suggest you take this game at a steady, or even slow, pace. Rushing through it would 1. leave you rather confused in some areas, as the game is akin to a natural labyrinth and if you haven't been paying attention, you're guaranteed to wander (unless you look up a guide) for quite a while. And 2. It would be doing a serious injustice to rush through and ignore the charming and interesting details put into this game.
.
Pros: Art, Music, Gameplay, Challenge, and Collectables are all amazing, at times the challenge can get a bit hard depending on your play style, but it's very much possible in the end (I went through on Normal. Easy grants you two extra items to help with health management, and Hard increases the number of enemies in the various rooms).
.
Cons: If you're rather impatient and don't like waiting around for possible secrets to unveil themselves (specifically in the Subterranean Grave is the one that annoyed me the most), you will have to take long routes back. My advice, as stated earlier: take the game slow and steady, be aware that there's going to be secrets in every area (there's an item you can buy that makes a noise when there's a secret yet to be found in a room, this is a completionist's best friend) and if you're struggling to find something, think it over, and use what you have at your disposal.

This is the game that got me into metroidvanias. This game is amazing, and worth it at full price, let alone sale.

115614456.review:
Honestly not a lot to say about this game.

	Momodora is a light 'Metroidvania'. Sure, the pathways diverge, but there's only, perhaps, 3 or 4 points where the paths substantially go in seperate ways. Otherwise they always wrap around to each other or lead to dead ends. When heading in the right direction you're mostly going in a linear path. So you won't get confusion to any significant degree. Perhaps due to the short length the game never gets overly complicated in its map.

	Speaking of, they could've color coded the map to differentiate the different areas from one another. It doesn't help when you're trying to backtrack and don't remember exactly where a specific area is, so you have to go off memory. Especially when you can transform as a cat, and can backtrack to gather that one optional item (that gives you no benefit except money).

	There's a battle system comprising of the same 3 hit combo and ranged arrows. By 2016 (its release date), you'd expect more from a combat system. Momodora plays like something from 1991 with its basic 3 hit melee attack. There's no huge flaw here, it's just oddly simplistic. 

	The ranged attack has definite problems, though. The arrows are unleashed via a button; they generally do very little damage. They can be charged for a stronger volley, but you'll also lose the charge easily. Dodged? Charge lost. Climbed a ladder? Inexplicably lost the charge. You can even lose the charge if you let go off the arrow button too early, which messes up the, "charge while melee attacking" strat sometimes. It takes a decent amount of time to charge, so that hurts.

	With that said, the arrows aren't at the point where they make your melee attacks worthless. So it's decently balanced, even with the charge issues. I just wish you had more nuance to the combat, but given that the enemies are just as simple it's not a surprise.

	The real angle here is the sprite work. Like everything else, the sprite work isn't complex. But it's attractive in its simplicity. Some of the background work is wallpaper-tier. Just as everything else, I wasn't astounded in this respect either, but I did appreciate the quality. The music also nets its share of praise, but I find its overstated for what's here. It's good, but not exemplary.

	Reverie under the Moonlight is actually the 4th Momodora game, in a series dating back to 2010. It's a prequel; not that it matters given how little story it has. It's a solidly made game, and far more polished than anything before it. But it simultaneously has no deep alure to it either. It's a weird spot to be in when your game has no issues and is competently made, but is also easily forgotten. It definitely gets far more praise than it merits, but it's definitely not a bad game at all.

	Recommended? If you have time to kill. But that's not really a recommendation, is it?

114295113.review:
Played with keyboard.
This review can apply to all difficulties, as I don't actually talk about how easy/hard this game is.

[h1]Positives[/h1]
[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
[list]
[*][h3]Movement[/h3]
Movement is very crisp and responsive feeling. No "floaty" feeling that I absolutely hate in platformers.
[*][h3]Combat[/h3]
Combat is equally good feeling. The 3-hit combos and aerial attacks lead into good stuns which is satisfying. Bow shots are snappy and zip across the screen. Charged shots pack a large punch, which makes the wait worth it.
[*][h3]General Enemies[/h3]
Enemy placement is generally good. Most of the time, you can either play aggressively to quickly clear a screen, or play safer and pick enemies one at a time. General enemies are all unique and don't seem to have any BS attacks. They are well telegraphed and easy to learn.
[/list]
[h2]Art and Music[/h2]
Both are great. The pixel art is pretty and ages well. This game has a strong visual identity. The music is pleasant in the background. I believe it conveys the eerie and melancholic atmosphere well. The music during boss fights open up to create a tense feel, without being intrusive. One of my favorite tracks is "Pardoner's Dance" vs Fennel. It's easily the standout piece of the entire game.


[h1]Neutrals[/h1]
[h2]Bosses[/h2]
This section still skews towards the positive side. The bosses are all really unique with their own quirks. Overall, they're very fun to tackle, but some attacks don't seem as well telegraphed as enemies. Either I'm unobservant or they really don't telegraph well. I noticed some minor viability problems, such as Lubella's falling orbs. The initial particles are a bit hard to pinpoint before they form into solid orbs.


[h1]Negatives[/h1]
[h2]The Map[/h2]
This definitely isn't a deal breaker, but I found myself having a hard time navigating around the world. One screen can take up multiple grids of the map, so sometimes it's unintuitive when traversing. The map shows where rooms are connected/disconnected, but I think it's slightly difficult to read.

Combat feels slow, the char goes forward while you attack, causing you to bump unintentionally into enemies, and feels like the first area extend for too long, with the same boring enemies. 

Some questionable decisions like platforms moving veeeeeery slow to make have to waaaaait a looot, the first boss killing you in 2 hits with a fast and badly telegraphed move, and the first town not having music, it gives the impression of a very amateurish game, despite the awesome graphics. The char movement feels very off.

I wish I played this game before the 2 week deadline, so I could refund this.

112134755.review:
Yes, this is a good game worthy of one's time who enjoys a nice Metroidvania game. 

It isn't too long, I beat in 20 hours with a 10 hour finishing time. The graphics are really nice without being realistic or overly complex. The sprites are cute and I really love the boss with the big...uh....milk producing glands, lol. I like the music and it fits the scenery well. 

It is challenging but, not too hard. It took me a few attempts to beat each boss, which is perfectly fine with me. Just keep at it, even a below average skilled gamer should be able to beat this with practice and determination. Figuring out how to get the true ending wasn't too hard, it just required some back tracking and paying attention. 

My only gripe probably isn't the fault of the developer but, the controls on my PS3 controller would go apeshit in the menus. Without even touching any buttons, the cursor would move about. This didn't happen during game play so I'm a little puzzled myself. It is probably my controller but, why didn't the main character go apeshit during gameplay?

Overall, an above average metroidvania game worth your time and munny stars. :)

110483867.review:
This game is gorgeous. The art is incredible and imaginative. I wish I could get lost in it. I feel pretty tepid towards this game, which for a game this beautiful, is a sign something is a bit off. Consider this a mixed review.

The core of the game, the combat, feels pretty lackluster. When I play a game, I want the game to test my skills as I get better. It shows me the ropes, but it does that to throw me down a flying fox. Momodora RUtM does not do that. The bossfights often felt more like an exercise in waiting down a timer than a tightly designed contest of skill, which is made worse by the alternate ranged attack, which does only a small amount of damage but is very safe to use.

Maybe that's wrong, maybe the exploration, the collectables, the experience of existing in such a nice world is the core of the game. I think overall, this is a death by a thousand cuts. The combat would be good enough for a game this short! ...if only the pacing was tighter. Why is the pacing loose? ...Because of the map design, and the lack of directions you're given, and the lack of variety when backtracking!

This game will hit the sweet spot for some people. It's difficulty will land just right, and they'll be able to wallow in it's decadent atmosphere like a hippo in a mudpit. If you think that's you, give it a shot!

109829824.review:
tl;dr - Great game, but harder than you might expect.  Easier difficulty mode(s) available.

I found myself returning to the imaginative (if bleak) world of Momodora, and in particular RUTM, and finding it a much less hospitable place than I recall.  In fact, it wasn't until about halfway through again that I recalled "oh yeah; I used to die a lot.  Okay."  Which is a testament, in and of itself, that the game's considerable (but not crushing) difficulty barely registered on me the first time through.

Momodora RUTM oozes charm, with its gorgeous pixel art, brooding atmospheric storytelling and exquisite gameplay.  While the backtracking and 'Metroidvania' elements are present, they're not really the focus of the game.  The story, the art and the fantastic characterisation is.

Give RUTM a try - you're not likely to be disappointed.

109762265.review: I would recommend this game for sure, I even liked it enough to get all the achievements... but I will absolutely admit that its not for everyone. It does not play like a platform fighter- The attacks are something more like Dark souls. They are a lot more deliberate and clunky; poorly timed attacks often leave you open to attacks. There is also no directional attack variations. You get a basic 3 hit combo, an aerial attack and a bow. The bow can be charged up, and you get a dodge-roll. Its a different feel than most metroidvanias so just know what you are getting into.

108742259.review:
[h1]Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight – Una lúgubre atmósfera.[/h1]
[b]Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight[/b] es la cuarta entrega de la saga de plataformas Momodora, saga en la cual su creador [b]rdein[/b] ha trabajado a lo largo de su carrera como programador de videojuegos, tomando como inspiración una serie de elementos de diversos juegos como Mega Man, Castlevania y por supuesto, su más grande inspiración: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/200900/Cave_Story/]Cave Story[/url]. Logrando combinar lo mejor de cada mundo para formar a lo largo del tiempo su propia formula e identidad, con una abismal mejora tanto en el apartado técnico como narrativo y brindando un gran cierre a esta icónica saga. 🍁

[h1]La maldición de la reina…[/h1]
Momodora IV sucede 400 años antes del primer título de la saga y nos cuenta la historia de Kaho Reinol, una sacerdotisa a la cual se le ha concebido la sagrada misión de detener una maldición que ha estado corrompiendo las tierras de la ciudad Karst y se ha esparcido lentamente hasta llegar hasta su pueblo natal Lun. En el camino, nuestra joven protagonista explorará inhóspitos lugares, sorteará diversos peligros, luchará contra monstruos y formará aliados hasta lograr la manera de obtener una audiencia con la Reina de Karst para salvar la tierra de su maldición. Una de las características a resaltar del diseño de juego es lo sutil que llega a ser el título, gracias a las diversas animaciones y diálogos adicionales con ciertos personajes al cumplir ciertas acciones o desbloquear ciertos objetos, añadiendo de esta manera una capa de profundidad que envuelve constantemente el juego y la experiencia que recibirás, haciendo sentir el mundo más orgánico y basto por explorar. Detalles así y muchos más pasarán desapercibidos en tu primera partida, pero son elementos que te sacarán una grata sorpresa gracias a su dosis de rejugabilidad intrínseco.

[h1]Mecánicas sólidas, combinaciones y adaptativo.[/h1]
La saga de Momodora siempre se ha caracterizado por la gran influencia que ha tenido en su creador el género Metroidvania y en este nuevo título no es la excepción, manteniendo muchos de los conceptos vistos en su anterior título de manera ferviente y potenciando otros, generando así una diversidad y versatilidad en las situaciones de nuestro viaje. Kaho, nuestra personaje; podrá realizar ataques cuerpo a cuerpo con su característica hoja de otoño y símbolo en el logo de toda la franquicia, así como a su vez ataques a distancia con un arco. Todo esto sin mencionar la diversidad de objetos que encontraremos y podremos equipar para potenciar nuestros hechizos y habilidades ya establecidas, permitiendo acceder a nuevas áreas para ampliar nuestro panorama del viaje. En todo momento sentirás el dominio total de tu personaje con una serie de movimientos y controles para nada molestos y totalmente responsivos al instante con cada una de las acciones que quieres realizar, cada error que pueda surgir en las secciones de plataformas o combates serán meramente culpa de la parcial carencia de habilidad del jugador, pero que una vez logra respetar, practicar y sumergirse en las reglas del mundo, se podrá superar cada uno de los retos propuestos y otorgando a su vez, todo un viaje rico en desafíos y destreza de principio a fin. Ya que si bien, su dificultad no es excesivamente elevada o abrumadora; resultando ser bastante accesible para todo público, es un juego que no hay que subestimar o tomarse a la ligera.

[h1]Estética evocadora y desesperanzadora.[/h1]
Cada visual que nos presenta ésta reciente entrega tiene un gran cariño y lujo de detalle en cada esquina, desprendiendo un carisma y belleza particular de su desarrollador. Todo enemigo denota su actitud o personalidad con sus animaciones o su simple diseño. Los ambientes son bastos, dinámicos en atmosfera e imersivos; sientes la pesadez de un mundo que ha dejado de brillar en la gloria y virtud, pasando a ser nada más que un vago recuerdo y un lugar lúgubre donde la fe de cada uno será su propia destrucción, todo esto y más momentos transmitidos con una estética pixel-art de forma magistral y con un gran cuidado en la presentación de la pequeña narrativa que posee, llegando en más de una ocasión ser hasta poética, reflexiva e inspiradora por sus particulares giros, gracias al acompañamiento de todo lo anterior expuesto.

[u]En conclusión:[/u] [b]Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight[/b] es una propuesta sumamente brillante y perfeccionada gracias a los años de experiencia y dedicación de un desarrollador y un equipo talentoso ([url=https://store.steampowered.com/search/?developer=Bombservice]Bombservice[/url]). Es una pequeña joya Indie que si bien no innova o revoluciona el mercado a través de grandes propuestas, los elementos tradicionales que plantea de su género, los desarrolla con ingenio y giro de perspectiva haciendo sentir un aire totalmente fresco y un sentimiento de un mundo vivo y verosímil. Una dificultad por encima de la media, pero que sigue siendo accesible para todo tipo de jugadores, una estética muy marcada a lo largo del tiempo y que cada vez deja relucir en cada entrega un potencial artístico visual, acompañado de una banda sonora sublime y formando en un todo, una experiencia entrañable y memorable en su tipo. [b]Totalmente recomendado y que no deberías dejar pasar por alto.[/b]

108609885.review:
[h2] Let's take a look at the steam store description! [/h2]
[quote=steam store page] Beautifully animated graphics [/quote]
The graphics and animations are good, I'll give them that. Though I don't care at all for the anime aesthetic and the enemy designs can be pretty forgettable

[quote=a lunatic] Exciting action gameplay: pull off impressive combos, dodge attacks, and skewer enemies with arrows [/quote]
Did I play the right game? You have a melee attack with a 3 hit combo (with endlag and drift). 
The most impressive combo you can pull off is chaining a jump attack into a 3-hit, for a devastating... 4-hit combo... that bosses will just stagger out of. And enemies get staggered by any melee anyway...

For the WHOLE game, you're stuck with this single melee combo, a jump attack, arrows, and charge shots that are effectively useless outside of entering combat

[quote=someone who hasn't played the game] Intense boss battles with challenging patterns and epic scale [/quote]
Yeah uhhh the bosses themselves just come out of nowhere. They pretend like they're super epic and meaningful but really they just make me more jaded to this game's ""storytelling"".
Epic scale? Well there's one boss that's big... just one that appears twice. I was completely un-invested by the final boss.

As for the gameplay side... THEY ALL HAVE 3-4 ATTACKS AT MOST, except for a shining exception that slightly changes attacks in phase.

Incredibly easy to memorise patterns, but the telegraphing is so poor in an absurd way that you'll get hit unfairly constantly. And considering how the bosses all 2-shot you, and usually have far away checkpoints, get ready for a lot of obnoxious trial and error.
-or facetanking. Their contact damage is basically free i-frames.

Hell, sometimes the boss patters are so easy, you get killed trying to over-dodge the fucking things, or you just get bored, stop paying attention or try to rush, and get one-shot. Real good stuff 

[quote=satan]Difficulty settings appropriate for all types of players―from story and setting lovers to hardcore action enthusiasts[/quote]
Easy mode: laughably easy.
Medium: difficult probably.
Hard: makes you want to kill yourself.
Insane: you die in one hit.
Too bad the level and boss design is shit so every difficulty will feel unfair and frustrating.

[quote=who???] A breadth of items that can be combined to facilitate new strategies [/quote]
Hmm let me see
[list]
[*] Mandatory healing item
[*] Damage buff that doesn't last long enough and bosses usually have i-frames too
[*] Big damage buff that hurts you. A good way to make the fights more bearable
[*] 3 spells that are fucking impossible to cast in bosses because they have a 3 second casting animation you must finish
[*] Orb to turn into a cat: the objectively more fun way to experience the melee combat. But you can't shoot or use items.
[/list]
Passive items?
[list]
[*] 3 money collecting items
[*] an item to find secret rooms (aka walls you have to slice despite them being indistinguishable)
[*] faster arrow speed (literally useless)
[*] piercing arrows: very nice in rooms
[*] status resistance: THERE'S 2 STATUSES IN THE FIRST 3 AREAS OF THE GAME
[*] status on weapon attacks or some shit: idk I think they're mostly drops you get from perfecting a boss or are expensive. Never got any
[/list]
Those are the items. They barely matter at all

[quote=uhhh] An amazingly diverse world to explore, filled with secrets and treasures [/quote]
[b] Secrets: [/b] random indistinguishable walls you have to hit.
[b] Treasures: [/b] money (for buying useless items) or hp upgrades
[b] Diversity: [/b] Yeah there's like 8 areas I guess but the enemy and level variety don't really exist

[quote=lies] Eccentric allies and foes with compelling personalities [/quote]
What?? There's no allies! And the foes get about 0-4 lines of super cringe tropey dialogue before they fucking die and never return.

[quote=skinwalker] Mysterious lore and rich backstory woven into events, dialogue, and item descriptions [/quote]
[b]Events:[/b] guy dies, this kingdom is very sad and grim ;((((
[b]Rich backstory:[/b] "we explain nothing and nothing matters, but if you read the lore, you'll know what we're talking about!"
[b]Dialogue:[/b] cringe, out of place, expository.... The NPCs are all just glorified sign-posts
[b]Item descriptions:[/b] more shit that I don't care about. Wow ok grim curse or whatever. The story doesn't exist

[quote=aliens]Then there’s also the story itself, which is also a masterpiece in game storytelling: a strange, mysterious world that you inhabit with countless hopeless souls whom you are trying to save. There is painstaking detail in every item, every snippet of dialogue. You find yourself constantly readjusting how you feel about these people. You're trying to save them, but do they even want to be saved? Or should you be more worried about that awkwardly sinister tone in their voices...?[/quote]
This is a [u]BLATANT. LIE.[/u]
The story is nonexistent. Just some dialogue, which I can't tell whether it tries too hard, or not at all.

There's like 3 instances of yes/no choices that either give you dialogue from a 0-dimensional person, or a story beat I've grown far too jaded to care for in the slightest.

The NPCs are almost ALL out of place and do nothing, the items have deep ~~[i]implied lore[/i]~~ but no actual significance. The "sinister tone"... I honestly don't know what they meant by that. But they try too hard with it.
There's even like 2 boss fights that only happen because of a stupid assumption.

And did I care about these people? [u]No. Not a single bit.[/u] The story is actually nonexistent. The atmosphere and dialogue are cliche as hell. The dark themes don't exist either. And the "lore" is a crutch for not actually having any fucking storytelling at all.

[quote=the publisher] Momodora: RUTM shouldn’t exactly be categorized as “Metroidvania” or “Souls-like”, but there certainly are elements of both contained within. It's a game of its own, and it’s one of the best entries in the mind-bogglingly expansive genre of side-scrolling action-platformers. We at Playism all love the game, and we can state with absolute confidence that if you’ve bothered to read this far, then you certainly will, too. [/quote]
More lies.
First of all, it's barely a platformer. You have a crap double jump and an imprecise air dodge. There's no interesting platforming. Unless enemies knocking you off counts as engaging. 
Also there's instadeath pits and spikes.... in a platformer...

"Metroidvania"? It's effectively linear. The only "exploration" you ever unlock that isn't a specific key is when you unlock Cat form. And that [i]only[/i] allows you to get more lousy HP upgrades.

"Souls-Like"? Yeah maybe if in Dark Souls you die instantly from everything on your way anywhere and are unfairly punished for trying to do fun things. Oh, and in dark-souls your weapon sucks, I think? Yeah this game has that too I guess. And a healing flask. It's basically dark souls.

[quote=nobody] Music [/quote]
Oh uhhh, it exists? I think? I remember 2 distinct songs playing... I can't remember what they were like though. I think almost all the areas are silent. 


And since I didn't have anywhere else to put this: I quit due to missing a shortcut to a checkpoint near the second boss. After dying to it like 2 times, I made it to the second phase... where I had to hit a giant witch in the boobs.
I just uninstalled instantly. Then a friend convinced me to go back and do the whole thing. Was it worth it? Yeah area 2 is by far the worst, but the game still sucks.

[hr][/hr]

CONCLUSION: this is the most overrated game I have EVER played and I am absolutely astonished at its reviews and how much everyone likes it. It is a paragon of outdated, bad design and mediocrity. Maybe I'm really bad at souls-likes, but I can't be convinced that this game isn't a bad souls-like itself

Play Hollow Knight instead. For the love of god

107502158.review:
An excellent 2D soulslike/metroidvania. It's pretty simple as far as mechanics go, search for powerups to gain new abilities to use to reach new areas, but there's also light RPG elements with lots of items to collect that have various usages such as temporarily making your weapon do more damage or making enemies drop more money. Similar to Dark Souls, there's an estus system which you can upgrade as you go. The combat is a bit stiff especially at first, but it gets better as you gain new abilities and the bosses are all pretty fun and not TOO difficult to defeat which is cool, it definitely doesn't lean towards Dark Souls in terms of difficulty.

Generally if you enjoy the gameplay loop of Dark Souls or are into Metroidvanias you'll enjoy this one, I always see this one on sale for cheap too so I recommend picking it up during a discount

On a metroidvania streak/binge, I encountered numerous references to Reverie Under the Moonlight.  I read a few articles and quickly realized I could play its precursors, Momodora 1 and 2 for free.  As a long-time Cave Story fan, I was immediately hooked and played through each.  I played through and 100%'ed Momodora 3 prior to this game.

All three featured increasing levels of polish and depth.  It was fun to see the evolution towards what RUtM would become, and I think gave me that much more appreciation for this excellent title.
