107273693.review:
Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight
Completion Time: 6.7 Hours
Platform Completed On: PC
Difficulty: Hard

	       Momodora is a MetroidVania which has taken a lot of cues from From Software games.  This game has quite a lot of pros and a few cons which I will explain while critiquing the ever-present categories of story, gameplay, world design, music and sound design, art and graphics, and main mechanics.

	       Let’s start with the category in which I think I have the most real-world experience: art and graphics.  Momodora is a pretty pixel game with colorful characters and locations.  All the enemies are unique from each other and most have interesting designs.  The bosses look especially good.  I don’t think there were any areas that I found myself confused with animations or anything of the sort, so overall, the game is communicative and stylish at the same time.  In the category of art and graphic design, Momodora scores an 10/10.
	Next, we have the gameplay.  As I said in the introduction, this game takes a lot of cues from the games made by From Software such as the Dark Souls series, but it also takes a lot of tropes from standard 2d platformers.  There is a dodge-roll that has I-frames and a great many items that have both gameplay use and lore/story implications.  The dodge-roll, however, is not as integral a feature as it is in the Dark Souls games.  I believe it would be entirely feasible to complete the game without the roll, especially since I did a great deal of my dodging with the standard movement options otherwise.  There are quite a few items that I found quite useful and even fun.  In a classic Souls fashion, there is even a hyper-mode that you can achieve using a couple items in combination to help you deal out an obnoxious amount of damage.  In addition to these other abilities and items, there is also a ranged attack that you start with which gets upgrades throughout the game.  There are a few side-quests, only one of which did I actually finish to get the true ending of the game.  The bosses are fun, challenging, and inspired.  The enemies are unique in their attacks and movement.  My only gripe with the game is that it suffers from the same problem as Dark Souls games.  It doesn’t in any way need a difficulty slider as I don’t think the game is made for it, even though I did play on hard (which was the hardest difficult available to me).  The game increases its difficulty by adding more enemies, increasing their damage, and decreasing the amount of health that you start with (and probably end with.  This is cranked up to the point where early-game enemies can one or two-shot you.  This isn’t all bad, but the difficulty feels very shallow and feels like it falls off pretty early once you pick up one of the many health upgrades.  Overall, the game is fun, even with its difficulty choices.  The game also has NG+ as well as an “insane” mode after the completion of hard mode.  In the category of gameplay, Momodora scores a 9/10.

	       World design is up next.  This game is heavily reminiscent of Metroid games in terms of the map and world layout.  The player moves from screen to screen similarly to Metroid or Mega Man.  There are secret breakable walls to access special areas and items.  Bosses can be fought in a non-linear fashion and areas can be accessed similarly.  The world is pretty connected with each area usually connecting to at least three other areas.  I was satisfied with the distance between save points and the late addition of the ability to warp between them.  Overall, I think the world design was well done.  In the category of world design, Momodora scores a 9/10.  

	       Story was a surprisingly big part of this game, even though it had the clear influence of From Software games.  The story, heavily summarized, is that you play as a priestess named Kaho who is on a journey to stop the spread of, and hopefully cure, a curse that has spread to her village using the power of her leaf (which she uses as a weapon) and her faith.  The item descriptions are quite additive to the lore of the story, but the characters throughout the game do a pretty good job telling it to you through their actions and dialogue.  I was pleased with the characters and story for the most part.  In the category of story, Momodora scores an 8/10.

	       The music in the game wasn’t anything special, but it wasn’t anything abrasive either (in most cases at least).  The soundtrack sounds simple.  I think that’s the best way to describe it.  The instrumentals feel a little bare, but at least they are contextually fitting.  There was one “song” that was actually painful after listening to it for a long period of time, but I can’t remember which area’s ambiance it was.  Otherwise, as I said, I didn’t find most of the music abrasive in any way.  In the category of music, Momodora scores a 6/10.

	       I think I can confidently say that the game’s main mechanic was that the vast majority of the characters (enemies, NPCs, and otherwise) were female.  If I recall correctly, only one character was male, and one boss was debatably male.  Otherwise, the entire cast was female.  Fun and “cultured” mechanic, scores 10/10.

	       I honestly really enjoyed this game.  I enjoyed it enough to play it in one long sitting, and I feel like I never do that.  I can confidently recommend it to any Dark Souls fans who also like a bit of fanservice mixed with platforming.

Cumulative Score: 52/60

PRO: 
- Beautyful pixelart
- Ok-ish music overall
- Genuinely feels like a SNES game

CONS:
- Character control feels very finnicky, especially the double jump
- Inconsistent gameplay: sometimes you can dive into the water, sometimes you die if you enter it.
- Unfairly punitive: spikes that one-shot you in the next room entrance
- Uninteresting story and NPCs, cheesy writing: I might have appreciated the game more if it didnt try to push me its uninteresting story or to make me care for flat NPCs I met just once.

All in all I found Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight quite a forgettable and mediocre experience and I cant feel to recommend it considering there are a lot of better alternatives on steam (Iconoclast, Hollowknight, Guacamelee!)

105334245.review:
A great little metroidvania. Much better than most of the other small cheaper ones out here, defininely worth playing I'd say. The core story and experience is pretty short, but it feels good, has some clear story, progresion, interesting enviornments and enemies, and is overall pretty solid and tight in its controls and gameplay. There's a good number of extra things to hunt for if you really want to, and to challenge yourself with like collecting the items or such for a bit of extra time.

If you want something with a much higher and more detailed story, this is lacking as it keeps it more simple and vague, a little bit like Dark Souls in that regard, they pull off the feel at least, but the underlying story is still a thousand times simpler, but it does feel nice for the most part.

My biggest praise is that it's ballanced, sort of. More recent games I've tried like Skull, Dead Cells, etc... have a focus on randomness in their content. And such systems tend to result in you just sometimes getting back luck, in fact most of the time having sub par luck, and not having the best or desired gear or equipment or enemies for what you have so you just have a really hard and sometimes downright unfair type of time. None of that in this game. You can reliably enough beat the entire game with your default attacks without taking a single hit between bell visits (bonfires, mini save points). In fact that's the insane difficulty, you die if you ever take one hit. And it was honeslty quite refreshing, when I fight the enemies I learn their skills, and counter them with my pre built abilities they are designed to fight against. I always CAN beat them fairly. Now, that said if you're not as good or just want it to be easier, there's easier difficulties and even on harder ones some great items you can get that franklly when stacked in the right ways can power through some bosses entire health in literally seconds by burning these, so you can get overpowered to an extent if you want. Though it's also worth saying these best items are mainly gotten by beating bosses without taking any damage, do that and they drop their special loot. Some of it can be bought at merchants otherwise but it's often pricey that way.
Overall, good game, nice atmosphere and entertaining combat. I replayed it several times and did bother to do the insane difficulty run beating all main bosses with no hits (there's an optional one I plan to try that with later but expect her to be harder than any other boss on insane by a notable bit).

103995597.review:
Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight is a very short, challenging, and more or less fulfilling Metroidvania game with very adorable pixel graphics and some dark but mostly well done storytelling.

The pixel art aesthetic and looks makes the game feel both antiquated but also fresh. The locations, scenery, and tone of the game are very well translated through the artstyle and while at times it could get a little tough to discern the foreground from the background, overall it was very nice. 

The gameplay, at the very least at the very beginning, can be very tedious. Your movement is limited to a double jump and a roll at the very start, with enemies that can kill you in 2-3 hits and a lot of repetition from death. This could make some players leave the game very early on, but once you reach about the halfway point and obtain two very important items, movement in this game becomes much much faster and a breeze in a lot of cases.

The combat is pretty simple, with a short range melee attack which can hit both on the ground and in the air, as well as a long range attack which can be charged (after getting 2 certain ingame items this can become the best attack method), and a variety of enemies, at least in terms of design. They can all be killed in 2-6 hits, and since you cause a lot of hit stun when attacking them, they aren't ever really an issue. 

Items in this game are near critical for making this game more tolerable both movement wise and combat wise. You can purchase an item which replenishes your health after defeating each enemy, an item that makes your long range attack have a poison affect, etc. You will have to explore and grind for money to obtain some but it is very worth it once you have them.

Overall, the game is pretty short, it only took about 5 hours to complete total, and the enemies and bosses, while sometimes cheap feeling, and really much of a hassle and can be dealt with relatively quickly (especially when using your long range attack).

I loved many aesthetics about this game, the visuals, the atmosphere, the UI, it was almost perfect like a 2D dark souls or even blasphemous; everything about the pixel graphics were great except the words were extremely hard to read.

Unfortunately  the game is full of cheap shots: enemies appearing behind you, touching a spike or a foot of water instant kills you and the save point is always somewhere far away from where they pull these tricks on you. Dying means you go all the way back to your last save point. 

I did enjoy some boss fights that were hard but fair, but for real the common enemy can 2 shot you OFF SCREEN and you have no way of knowing where they are and your bow will not hit them either. Controls are a bit clumsy (Q is dodge while A is jump and S is melee, imagine that). After my 20th or so death and having to run all the way back to the same point I was before dying again I finally gave up. Maybe in another year I'll play it again.

99532833.review:
This is a really underrated game and probably one of the better Metroidvanias out there. I would absolutely recommend it to fans of the genre, especially if you like stuff like Touhou as well. It certainly isn't Hollow Knight (I don't think that game will be surpassed for a long time, its genuinely the crown jewel of the genre to the point where Metroid and certainly Castlevania's names should probably just be replaced in its nickname with Hollow Knight-like), but it is a great choice for scratching that itch again should it ever come up. 

Momodora's aesthetic combines the brightly colored, constantly shifting and afterimage-creating neo-32-bit goodness of Cave Story, the elegant "everyone and every monster is a girl" nonsexual cuteness of Touhou, and the melancholic heft of, well, Hollow Knight or Bloodborne to create a perfect balance between a comfort game and a more weighty action-platforming adventure. Its difficulty level is complementary, too, with enemies being tricky enough that you can't just blaze through like an idiot spamming healing, but likewise without any really absurd or sadistic encounters that mark the game out as a hardcore test of reflexes. Arguably the most significant aspect of this game is its sound design. The sharp, compressed MIDI-bass sound of your adorable, pastoral priestess heroine striking enemies with her enchanted leaf is every bit as snappy and satisfying as Hollow Knight's nail, and the music tracks perfectly reflect the pretty, girly melancholy that the game itself exudes, to the point where its fun to listen to by itself, your fond memories of the game alone being enough to keep it company. 

The level design is just servicable, and the game overall is short but sweet, with the difficulty and mechanical innovations being probably not significant enough to pose an interest for real nuts and bolts loving skill based gamers. But for what it is, that being a $20 Metroidvania, Momodora's very respectable vibes are enough to make it a gem worthy of much more than the recognition it has gotten. Maybe before you play another 2D graphics Dark Souls III hoping that it will give you back what beating Hollow Knight took away from you, give this game a glance.

98688279.review:
This is one of those instances where the game is good BUT you need to take into consideration some things

For the good I can say the art is beautiful and the combat is solid, fluid and intuitive. Yes, the game is hard (more so depending on the difficulty and if you're aiming for some of the trophies) but you can't really call it unfair as you'll be more or less okay if you master the mechanics

Some things to consider:

-The game is short. I started it on a friday and finished it on a sunday by playing it initially on hard without previous knowledge. Like other games, you get to a point where you understand how to dodge or avoid damage, making it easier than what it looks.

-The story is not all that interesting. I know this isn't the first game in the series but it's one of those where there's lore on the item description and the characters tell you snippets of the story and what happened. I don't have a complete problem with that but I feel it's kind of a crutch to make it seem "Deep".

-The attacks are very basic. I know I said before the combat is solid but it's attached to how you only have one combo and one shooting attack. As you probably know this means a lot of getting close to a boss, combo it, get out quickly, throw some arrows, rinse and repeat. I went into the game thinking you would have a loadout of weapons or something but that's not the case. There's some accessories to help you on your way but that's pretty much it 

-The achievements are BS. I've never liked those "complete the game without dying" or "complete the game avoiding x thing that's all over the map" and I feel are only there to squeeze more gaming time. I respect people that like it but it feels cheap that, if you like to see the completion mark in 100%, you need to grind and suffer

All in all, it's a very short experience but it's an experience nonetheless. I would recommend purchasing it only if it's on discount

98622798.review:
Momodora: RUtM es sin dudas mi metroidvania favorito. La estética, su música, los personajes y sobre todo su jugabilidad lo ubican en ese puesto (hacía rato que no me enganchaba tanto con un juego).

Algunas cosas a tener en cuenta si es que estas pensando en comprar este título:
-Lo corre casi el 98% de las pcs (requisitos mínimos muy bajos y 60 fps estables).
-Es un juego que recompensa muchísimo al jugador curioso: Su mapa es bastante grande, los paisajes son hermosos (se sacan capturas de pantalla 24/7) y las zonas están conectadas con lógica.
-Ideal si se busca un desafío: Momodora RUtM no es un título el cual se golpee todo lo que se cruza y así ir avanzando (a lo hack and slash). Los enemigos (en dificultad normal) con 3 o 4 golpes nos dan un game over (yo lo estoy terminando por 3era vez en dificultad insano, y hasta los minions más débiles te one shotean de un golpe). Por eso el juego brinda un botón de dodge, que nos permite esquivar el ataque enemigo y punishearlo (esto mismo pasa a la inversa: si se ataca sin pensar o a lo loco, el enemigo punishea).
-Diversidad de objetos que nos permiten armar diferentes builds para pasar el juego (muchísimo replay value con los items y las múltiples dificultades, sumado a los logros de steam).
-Los jefes, que no son muchos (10, 2 sub jefes y un jefe secreto) poseen personalidades únicas y logran ser memorables. Lo bueno de Momodora: RUtM es que al estar tan bien construidas las conexiones entre las zonas permite una exploración y orden de jefes para nada lineal (con esto me refiero a que, por ejemplo, el jefe del monasterio  fue mi cuarto jefe en la primera partido, el quinto en mi partida de dificultad difícil y ahora es el séptimo en mi partida en dificultad insano. Sin dudas mi jefe favorito).

Algunas cosas que no me gustaron:
-La visualización del mapa está todo en un mismo color; la única forma de saber cuál zona es "la de arriba del mapa" o "la que está a la derecha del mapa" es con la memoria (aunque como dije antes, al estar tan bien unido el mundo que el juego plantea, no es un gran problema).
-Algunos personajes secundarios pasan completamente desapercibidos y no aportan mucho a la narrativa.
-El lore, que es buenísimo, no se explota al 100% (igual, diría que se lo explota un 89%).
-New Game + no brinda mucho contenido extra al juego.

Cuando termine el juego en dificultad insano, haré una guía explicando builds recomendadas, objetos y orden de jefes para poder sacar el logro de steam.
Recomendadísimo 10/10, y esten hype por el Momodora: Moonlit Farewell

98420319.review:
Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight is a very good platformer. It has some non-linear level design, but not to the point where I would consider it a "metroidvania". Speaking of which, the level design is great, making the player use every tool at their disposal to traverse most of its world.

The story is quite simple. Kaho is a priestess from a faraway land who's come to cleanse a curse coming from the kingdom of Karst. Along the way she will meet some of the inhabitants of the kingdom, who will either lend her help or try to kill her. It's not particularly complex, but it does feature multiple endings, which gives the game some replayability, especially if the player's interested in getting every single achievement. 

In terms of presentantion: the music and sound effects are arguably the best part of Momodora: Without spoiling much, they add a lot of tension and a sense of dread to certain parts of the game. The artstyle may be adorable at times, but it definitely doesn't clash with the darker parts of the game. 

The gameplay is nothing special, sadly. The combat is well done and so is the platforming, with both being slower than most other games in the genre,  to the point some people consider it to be a Souls-like (A statement with which I disagree, but I can see why some people would say so). Kaho controls really well, mostly thanks to the controls being very responsive, although it might take a few minutes to get used to the timing of her attacks.

Overall, Momodora. Reverie Under the Moonlight is a great game. It's simple, yet effective in both gameplay and story. Biggest drawback for some might be the fact that it can be beaten in one sitting, but it might be a good reason to get it for others. It's a bit on the easier side, but I think most people who like platformers in general will love this one.

97871191.review:
Before I start the review, this does need to be said. Overall, this is a great game, however, it is very short. My first playthrough took about 3.5 hours with 99% map completion. This game is listed for 9.99 USD. So please keep that in mind before making your purchase. Anyway, moving on! 

Review is below! Final grade is the mean of the categories, while factoring in the asking price. Benchmark detailing what each numeral value means below.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Category & Grade[/th]
        [th]Review[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Graphics
8.5/10[/td]
        [td]The devs did a really good job on making the game look well. There are plenty of details in the backround, making the world look like an actual world, not just a barren canvas to move around in. Animations are beautifully done.   [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Music
8.5/10[/td]
        [td]Music in this game is catchy. Can go from tranquil, to immense, to downright grim and oppressive. Not every tune is a banger, but most are. It is also done well to where it makes you feel the weight of the position you are in. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Gameplay
8/10[/td]
        [td]In terms of metroidvania, does this game meet that benchmark for gameplay? Kinda... It certainly isn't as extensive as the norm goes, but you do backtrack a few times. Just rarely. The only time you can backtrack for missed content is twice, so it is very low for the genre's benchmark. Apart from that, the game performs without any issue. You have a leaf (pretty much your sword), and bow and arrow. You have items that act as active and passive abilities. You find hidden walls, NPCs to interact with and do quests for (hidden quests), and lots of exploring. My knocks for this game revolve around enemy variety. There is a lot to be desired. What they had was good, but I wanted more. Also you get one combo and that is it. No changing attacks. Just whatever you see at the beginning of the game is what you get.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Replayability
8/10[/td]
        [td]After beating the main game, you are offered to play new game+. There, enemy placement is different and they hit harder. You do retain your items and map discovery. There is also an unlockable mode called insane, which you get for beating hard mode. Each boss you fight gives you a unique item if you do the fight hitless. And there are achievements for not dying in a run, not killing common enemies in a run, and more. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Story
7/10[/td]
        [td]Story here is nothing to write home about, but thought went into it. Pretty much you are a priestess who is looking to confront the queen because of a curse that has spread to her lands. You then find out once reaching the city where the queen resides, everything went belly up. While what is there is good, I want more. I want lore, hidden memos, something that gives more more pieces to the puzzle. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Exploration
9/10[/td]
        [td]There are a lot of secrets to find in the game. Hidden passages, shortcuts and collectibles are out there for you to search. While not the most metroidvania game overall, it nails the exploration. And with the nicely designed world, you will find yourself wanting to see what else is out there. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]Final Grade
8/10[/td]
        [td]Again, keep in mind that you are buying a game that for your first run, will likely finish in 4 hours. That in mind, the game is priced at 9.99 USD. I will recommend it because for what it is, it is a solid game. It just is what I said before, short. Otherwise you should find enjoyment out of it through the exploration, boss battles, and music. [/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

97847782.review:
A bit of a sleeper here, a surprisingly solid and beautiful Metroidvania. The main draw is that it's very short, but it's an excellent game.
The gameplay feels precise, the art and music are very atmospheric and well done. It has a tone similar to Dark Souls, and it's also a fairly difficult game. I do not recommend playing on hard.
Story's a bit obscured, but I suppose that might be intentional given its inspiration. I don't quite remember the story or any of its "whys" so I suppose it's a negative.

97839271.review:
I've completed all the achievements of this game and i can say;
CONS: 
- Game is quite short, specially if you're experienced in Side Scrolling games. (I've beaten it under 4 hours in one go) 
- Has some Easter eggs, cameos, objects and dialogue that seems to bring upon objectives, but in reality they don't, and it ends up in a dead end. (Rip blue prisoner)
- Does not have checkpoints apart from save spots, and forgetting to save the game to die, will cause you to lose a ton of progress. (to be fair though, save spots are mostly close from each other)
-Can become infuriating or stressing at harder difficulties, as many enemies have really cheap ways to attack you and instantly kill you.
- Has few achievements, i think only 10? the game rewards you with goodies for killing bosses without taking damage or treating certain npcs a certain way, and not all achievements reflect that.
- Ladders are annoying, and this game has too much of that. Just spam jump button while climbing.

PROS:
- Graphics are lovable, mixing minimalist color palettes mixed with modern art styles. its notorious how much love they have in classic eras of gaming. a huge jump in looks from older Momodora games.
- Gameplay is addictive, great and challenging, trade in and out combat style having a powerful arsenal of attacks that encourages learning patterns while you push your greed on how many attacks you can get before having to dodge.
- You can become a kitten
- Exploration is amazing, with every dedicated area neither being too big or too small. Full of secret rooms, invisible walls and hidden passages, some easy to find and some as hidden and obscure that you will need the help of items to find them.
- The game does not have a clear order. you will find many paths, and you can do most of them as you please. yes, progression is locked behind keys in some areas, but you still have exploring as the main task, while the game gives objectives trough it.
- Items are the most important thing to add diversity and define play styles. Id recommend finding those that match and to try the ones that have negative effects on them too. you may find a good use for them.
- The player never feels overpowered to the enemies and bosses, and having low health in this game is scarier than any other game, as scrolling to the next screen will always respawn enemies, even if you have killed them before. You will grow to like this.

Consclusion:
Momodora RUTM is an amazing side scroller souls-like metroidvania, that has many mechanics to call their own. Its a very good experience for new players in easier difficulties and a rough challenge for hardcore players in its hard and last unlockable secret difficulty.  The game has a more firm emphasis in platforming and exploration than most games of its kind, raising more questions than answers since mystery and uncertainty rule trough start to its end, visible in its characters, backgrounds and lore.

-------[b][English & Brazilian Portuguese review][/b]-------

[b][English][/b]

[quote=][b]Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight[/b] is a metroidvania game.
The game was developed by Brazilian indie studio Bombservice and serves as a prequel to the first Momodora.[/quote]

[h1]History[/h1]
The story takes place 400 years before the first Momodora and puts us at the feet of the priestess Kaho, who travels to the Kingdom of Karst in order to stop the curse that plagues the kingdom.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As you progress, you'll be able to obtain skills, amulets that grant passive abilities, usable items, HP boosts, and key items (needed to progress). Also having a good variety of enemies and bosses, with an attractive visual style and most of the time very challenging. And with satisfactorily interconnected areas.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
Good soundtrack with decent variety of instruments. You will find several tracks with electronic instruments.

[h1]Characters[/h1]
In my opinion, one of the problems. You probably won't be able to remember anyone's name once you finish the game. The protagonist is the typical silent heroine, and other characters that appear don't have the slightest impact.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
- Good gameplay
- Good variety of enemies
- Good bosses
- Good soundtrack
- Beautiful graphic style
- Various ways and paths to progress in the game
- Good variety of items (both offensive and defensive)

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Few skills (but there are plenty of items to make up for it a little).
- Weak history
- Sexualization in boss Lubella, when attacking her breasts makes them sway, something you won't find anywhere else in the whole game, in my opinion being totally unnecessary.

[h1]Personal Score[/h1]
[b]Gameplay:[/b] [i]9/10[/i]
[b]Story:[/b] [i]7/10[/i]
[b]Characters:[/b] [i]6/10[/i]
[b]Soundtrack:[/b] [i]7/10[/i]
[b]Overall:[/b] [i]7.25/10[/i]

[quote=][b]Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight[/b] é um jogo do gênero metroidvania.
O jogo foi desenvolvido pelo estúdio indie brasileiro Bombservice e serve de [i]prequel[/i] para o primeiro Momodora.[/quote]

[h1]História[/h1]
A história se passa 400 anos antes do primeiro Momodora e nos coloca nos pés da sacerdotisa Kaho, que viaja para o Reino de Karst a fim de parar a maldição que infesta o reino, na qual também afetou sua vila.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
A medida que avançar, você poderá obter habilidades, amuletos que concedem habilidades passivas, itens usáveis, aprimoramentos de HP e itens chaves (necessários para progredir). Possuindo também uma boa variedade de inimigos e chefes, com um estilo visual atrativo e na maioria das vezes bem desafiador. E com áreas interconectadas de forma satisfatória.

[h1]Trilha Sonora[/h1]
Boa trilha sonora com variedade decente de instrumentos. Você encontrará várias trilhas com instrumentos eletrônicos.

[h1]Personagens[/h1]
Em minha opinião, um dos pontos fracos. Você provavelmente não vai conseguir lembrar o nome de ninguém assim que terminar o jogo. A protagonista é a típica heroína silenciosa e outros personagens que aparecem não causam o mínimo de impacto.

[h1]Prós[/h1]
- Boa jogabilidade
- Boa variedade de inimigos
- Bons chefes
- Boa trilha sonora
- Estilo gráfico bonito
- Várias formas e caminhos para progredir no jogo
- Boa variedade de itens (tanto ofensivos quanto defensivos)

[h1]Contras[/h1]
- Poucas habilidades (mas há bastante itens para compensar isso um pouco).
- História fraca
- Sexualização na chefa Lubella, onde atacar os seios da mesma os faz balançarem, algo que você não encontrará em nenhum outro momento do jogo todo, em minha opinião sendo totalmente desnecessário.

[h1]Nota pessoal[/h1]

97303408.review:
TL;DR: Very pretty, beautiful art and wonderful music. It's very short, even after getting both endings. 7/10 at least, but I can't recommend it.

The game is very cheap. But for 2 hours I don't feel I got a lot out of it - as I'm not much of an achievement hunter.

The game is challenging in a weird way. Entering a room one way can have enemies attack you from off-screen, but entering the opposite way can have the same enemies facing away and be easy targets for a quick kill. Combat isn't hard but when you get hit, you usually get hit very hard. However, healing or save points are usually not an issue. Some enemies have some really questionable hitboxes, so beware. Bosses are usually more fair, but still require some trial and error - though rarely frustrating.

The gameplay is what you'd expect from a Metroidvania. You can't go somewhere? Perhaps you'll get an ability to help you later, so remember to come back. Rub your face against the walls and look for hidden passages and try not to get lost. I got 98% map completion without effort. Navigation isn't too hard, thanks to a mostly comprehensive map that's only one button away.

You later get the ability to warp between save points. But it's a weird trade-off that I don't think I've seen in other Metroidvanias. You warp with save points, instead of warp rooms. That's a nice convenience. But you can only warp to SPECIFIC save points in each area, and the game doesn't show you where before you do, so you'll have to memorise it instead, or look up a map. Again, a trade-off. Not necessarily worse than other Metroidvanias, just not an outright improvement.

For the story? You're a priestess who's charged with ridding a city of a curse that's spreading. You do this by slapping the demons away with a giant leaf. Very nice! After that, it's whatever the NPCs tell you, but you probably don't need to worry about that. However, you don't really feel like the story is progressing at all. I had no idea I was getting close to, or fighting the final boss until I actually defeated them and suddenly got the Bad Ending. It caught be by surprise, since there was no build-up unless I literally missed it. All I could do was find out what I was missing and try again. And what are my thoughts?

Spoiler warning: [spoiler] I got the Bad Ending because I hadn't yet found a box of winds to spin a windmill (that I should have been able to rotate with my arms...) and dipped my leap in a puddle of water below, turning it green. After that all I had to do was go back to the same boss and defeat them in the exact same way. Only difference is that instead of TWO phases, now it had THREE. And what is the difference between the endings?

In the Bad Ending, you die from the curse, but don't lift it. Oops.

In the True Ending, you die from the curse, but lift it. Oh, but it's cool your spirit totally lives on and stuff. All that extra legwork really paid off. [/spoiler]

In the end, I'm just feeling disappointed by the experience. I primarily play for fun and feeling like I accomplish something, but your take on either may differ from mine. If so, you'll probably enjoy this game a lot more than I did.

97013340.review:
[code]For other game reviews, please [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/40640212/]follow us at What The Game?[/url][/code]

Holy cow. I purchased this game on a whim because of my desire to play something metroidvania style, and little did I know the gem that I had come across. Momodora:RUtM is nothing short of an absolute must have for your library. Not only is this game packing some great visuals, great animations, beautifully built worlds, but the gameplay is so spot on. The balance in platforming, bosses, and enemy types were all mixed into a very very well done, high energy combat experience.

Not only did the developers nail every aspect of this experience, but they even gave you more reason to play through multiple times with how great it is to play. This is definitely a title I see myself coming back to over the years just as Castlevania: Symphony of the Night has been. 

And don't let the cute aesthetics fool you; this game will kick your rear end. Some of these fights really do get tough and some segments really need your focus to be sharp. My only regret with the game is that I wish there was more of it because I didn't want it to end. In the future, this company will most certainly have me excited with anything else they release. Fantastic experience here that I would highly suggest any player should play.

94277836.review:
Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight is an indie Metroidvania-based game. You play as Kaho a mage who is sent on a mission to end the disturbance affecting the area. Upon doing so, you will meet a cast of characters/bosses that add more to the overarching story.

Personal Preface:
Momodora: RutM is my very first Momodora game. It is, apparently, the 4th title in the franchise. I was only introduced to this particular game since I knew some of the developers. As a good friend, I did help to spread publicity by word of mouth upon release. As  bad friend, I only recently played this game even though I knew about it well into development.

My first playthrough kept me very immersed in the Momodora universe. The mechanics of the game made me feel that this was a hybrid of games like Metroid/Castlevania, obviously, as well as other platform-based genres like Megaman. Adding new abilities and discovering new areas or enemies made the game fun and challenging. Even upon completing my first playthrough, there is an in-built incentive to play again. A New Game+ would invite you to finish exploring the map, and complete no-hit challenges against bosses. The community has also spurred on various challenges to increase the difficulty even more (dashless, leaf-only etc).

Overall, I found the art to be cohesive and visually pleasing without any major detriments. The character designs are interesting and enjoyable. Interactions with NPCs are more involved than you would assume. The music is fitting. From different areas like the marsh to the cathedral, the tracks encompass where you area in the story and the gravity of the scenario. A favorite track is Pardoner's Dance, a wonderful boss theme that uses piano to build the drama and tension of the battle. Yes, actual instruments, not chiptunes.

Not everything about Momodora: RutM is perfect. Is Momodora: RutM standalone? Was it designed to be? I felt that I was always an observer in this tale. While the driving motivation never waned, I think there were more questions than answers even by the end of the game. Perhaps the game is dependent on the history of the previous three or perhaps the universe is meant to be fragmented and disjointed. Hidden lore could have helped to alleviate this issue that retells the history or updates the player of the events leading up to present day. 

TL;DR version: Good game with nice art and music. My favorite cat transforming game.

93192216.review: This is a very good and very short game. If you have ever wanted a 2d platformer with some soulslike mechanics such as rolling, save points and refillable items, then there is a decent chance you will enjoy your time on it. It combines that with an interesting story with fun (and relatively easy) bosses all wrapped up in a metroidvania package. I did have some minor issues with the game such as the way spawn points were set and the warp mechanic. The warp system only takes you to a specific bell in an area and you have to work your way through enemies to get to whichever bell you need to be at to progress. This was somewhat frustrating at times considering that this game does promote backtracking in order to find special items and collectibles. This was coupled with the fact that warping doesn't set your spawn point to the bell you warped to, meaning you also have to make sure you set your spawn in case you die. Other than that, it was a fun and short game.

92386366.review:
[h1] An Important Note     [/h1]
Special thanks to my buddy Jp. For a good palate cleanser of a game.

[h1]One Priestess to Stop a Deadly Curse [/h1]
Basic premise/Story

From developer studio, Bombservice and directed rdein. Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight is an indie metroidvania where you play as a young priestess named Kaho as she journeys to the eastern kingdom of Karst to stop a curse that has been corrupting nearby lands including her village. 

[h1]A Leaf and a Bow? [/h1]
Unique Gameplay

The game oozes with 2D bit aesthetics that are both charming and minimalistic. There weren't a whole lot of systems involved to remember. Except using a bow and your leaf to attack enemies, consumables option and even some handy items/spells you can use during combat. Each giving off a passive or active effect. Momodora doesn’t even take that long to beat with my playthrough clocking at just a little bit over four hours. With 99% map completion. The music, while subtle, helped give to life many areas you will visit throughout the map in Momodora. Yet it doesn’t overstay its welcome. There are plenty of save options nearby to save your progress and restore your health and consumables while on the go. Usually bringing up the map and going back to places you previously couldn’t enter is recommended once you gain a key ability that will allow the player to traverse into the new zone. Making backtracking a breeze and using new abilities to traverse is fun. 

[h1]Moving the Curtain Aside.[/h1]
Final thoughts/Ruminations

To my utter surprise I was quite captivated by Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight. It’s been some time since I played a metroidvania game and I was hooked by how minimalistic the game details its world, inhabitants, lore and more without saying too much. While I would appreciate some more world-building to flesh out the game some more. I believe Momodora does an adequate job in selling the game’s premise to fans. There is no need to saturate the game further when it would break the balance and momentum of what the game already tries to convey to the player. Not much I can critique on the game, besides wishing for more music tracks. The gameplay was simple and effective by relying on the mechanics given at the start. Players can go deeper with combos in tandem to combat some bosses the game throws at you. In addition to some new abilities you will gain later on to help with traversal and combat. The story surprised me deeply and I couldn’t help, but be touched by the ending. Without any context, it goes into a direction I found fitting albeit one I didn’t expect at all. Still Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight is a must for newcomers or veterans of the metroidvania genre looking for something new, charming and short.

92385410.review:
Quick Description:
-Momodora Reverie Under the Moonlight is the 4th entry in the Momodora series and is hands down the most polished version of the series.  This is a cute, mini metroidvania that metroidvania fans are likely going to enjoy.  It's a one man team and is quite rough around the edges, but makes up for it w/ charm and engaging combat.

What's Good:
-This game has a ton of charm.  There are a lot of cute characters and npcs all over the map.  Even some of the larger than life bosses are adorable looking characters.  I like the contrast between the brutal combat and the cute characters.  There are enemies that kill in 2-3 hits and spikes that instantly kill you.  You would never expect that from such an adorable looking game.
-I'm a big fan of the pixel art.  I like the way the bosses look, the impact when you hit enemies w/ your weapons, and when small star-like currency flies out of dead enemies.  The environment itself is serviceable, although not as polished as top tier games.
-The boss fights are hands down the most fun and challenging part of this game.  There are a quite few bosses in this 5 hourish game.  Some of small and agile, while others are very imposing and towering above you.  These bosses hit hard and are tough.   Memorizing their patterns and equipping the right powerups are key to victory.
-Lots of secrets to find.  I really loved exploring the world.  This is not that big of a metroidvania and the map isn't great, but traversing the world is still really fun.  You will be heavily rewarded for checking every square inch the map.  Some secrets are really obvious, while others are more obtuse.  Being able to equip more health potions, finding powerful relics, or simply gaining health can all be found if you search hard enough.
-You have a basic short ranged four leaf clover and a long range bow.  I loved that they chose a four leaf clover to be used as a weapon.  It's small things like this that make Momodora stand out.  You can unlock powerups that make your arrows poisonous or add flames to your attacks.

Could Use a Few Changes:
-Very difficult during the first 2 hrs.  You are way under-powered and thrown into the deep in.  During the first 30 minutes, there are several enemies that can 2-hit you.  Even after the first hr, there are a ton of enemies that can 3 hit you.  There are also lots of instant death spikes to avoid while platforming.  This is going to cause a lot of players to give up before really enjoying the meat of this game.
-Pacing could use a lot of work.  I think this game would have benefit from adding one to two more areas and making this closer to a 8 hr experience.  Basically, as of right now, you spend your first two hrs dying left and right, then by the 4 hr mark, you become an incredibly overpowered tank that can brute force its way through almost everything.  If this game were a little longer, then they could have made the beginning a bit easier, and had a longer build up until you become extremely powerful.
-Most people do not enjoy one hit death spikes.  They are used quite a bit here, especially in the second half of the game.  There has to be more creative ways to add new challenges to the end of the game.
-Some areas of the map are kind of bizarre, and you can tell that this game lacks the polish that the best in the genre have.  You will also see quite a bit of duplicate enemies throughout the game.  Some enemies from the very beginning will also be at the very end in the same form.  This is not ideal imo.

Thoughts:
-I'm glad that I finally got around to playing Momodora.  I haven't played any of the other games in the series, but I've been told that this one is the best and most well rounded of the 4.  There is a final 5th game in the works which I'm excited to check out.  This isn't a perfect game but it's a competent metroidvania that fans of the genre should check out.  The dev was clearly inspired by Dark Souls and the challenging, methodical combat is one of the highlights of the game.

Consensus:
-Middle of the Road Game (Tier 4 and makes up 25% of my reviews).  It's only $10 new but is an absolute steal right now while it's on sale for $4.  If you are scrambling to binge another metroidvania, than Momodora Reverie of the Moonlight is a fun one worthy of your time.

The art direction and animations in this are my absolute favourites. The gameplay is also great. Movement is tight, and items are pretty useful, save for one or two. I also love the couple of rooms and side characters that give the world a lot more depth. It's a simple little game you can finish in an hour or so, unless you're going for all the secrets (there's more than you think). One tip: there's a body of water that has a ladder going downwards; you won't drown in that.

Plus, it's a really good first game to get into speedrunning, if you're into that. The learning curve isn't steep, and the speedrun chiefly relies on you perfecting your movement. And as I've mentioned, movement is tight, so you won't find yourself getting frustrated over controls (unless you're doing rolljumps, but that's another story) . For whichever category you decide to do, the upper bound for your first run would be an hour and a half, and getting down to 30-40 minutes shouldn't take you more than a couple of further runs. And lastly, you get to keep seeing the art and animations.

And yeah ha ha booba funni

Play as Kaho, the Priestess from the village of Lun! Lately, a terrible, terrible curse has spread across the lands, and the only way to fix it is for Kaho to travel from her homeland to the Kingdom of Karst to seek the aid of the Queen! However, not all is well in the kingdom.

While Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight is an adequate game, it’s really hard to say it’s any good until a couple hours in. Until you actually find upgrades and learn attack patterns, every enemy and boss can actually be pretty tough and will kill you if you don’t pay attention. Once all the upgrades are collected, the game is much easier, but the opponents stay exactly the same. Some of the enemies you find in the beginning are the same ones you find right before the final boss room and there really could have been a bit more variety. 
The biggest disappointment for me had to be the endings. While I’m not posting any spoilers about it, I probably wouldn’t have gotten the game at all if I had known.

Regardless of all it’s faults, it’s not a bad enough game for me to not recommend it, and if you are interested in playing Momodora, I suggest either looking up gameplay videos or reading more reviews first.  

TL;DR: It’s a decent game with subpar endings. Play it if you want.

90601346.review:
Momodora is a fun and sweet title that I recommend to every metroidvania fan.

The Positives

-The gameplay is in the style of your typical metroidvania, so don't expect any innovations here. If you love the genre, your enjoyment is guaranteed.
The pace is relatively fast but never so much that you can get away with just button smashing. Furthermore there are some sections that focus more on platforming and offer a decent break from the fighting.
-There are upgrades, items and secrets for the player to find but not so many that you end up spending hours upon hours to find out what to do to progress the game.
-This was one of my first metroidvanias and I found it accessible and endearing. A great introduction to the genre.
-The art and the soundtrack both looks amazing. I wish there was an exploration mode where one can just go around and talk to the characters of this world -that is how compelling Momodora looks and sounds.

The Negatives

-A bit easy during the first time one plays it. I died only a few times, all during boss battles and even those took no more than a third try.
-A little on the short side. I finished in 6-8 hours and I am but a newbie.

There has been real dedication in the making of this game and it shows. If you enjoy or are interested in metroidvanias, check Momodora out -it is worth full price and if you come across it's a steal.

90278343.review:
The TL;DR is: Combat is bad, enemy variety is poor, exploration is dull, almost no meaningful upgrades, and the bosses are forgettable.

I want to preface saying that I got all the achievements for this game so I did spend an adequate amount of time playing it.

It's fun enough to play, but is so burdened by flaws and annoyances that pile up into an overall rather unenjoyable experience. 

Map design ranges from annoying to downright poor design. The actual ingame map is poor, the entire map being just a bunch of red tiles instead of denoting a color for each major region. Additionally, it's filled with numerous one-way paths that make you waste time looping around just to continue exploring if you had the audacity to pick the wrong direction first. Several of these one-way paths are impossible to get back to until you get a late game upgrade, and I use "upgrade" very loosely here. 

Because for a Metroidvania, the game doesn't really have upgrades. And I mean actual, gameplay improving upgrades letting you advance your exploration ability. The only actual upgrade that does *anything* for exploration is being able to turn into a cat. The problem is this does nothing actually beneficial for you--you lose the ability to make ranged attacks and can't climb ladders (which are common in the game) so you have to spend most of your time as a human regardless. The only thing it lets you do that's special is walk through tight corridors. Those corridors are few and far between throughout the game, like the cat ability was an afterthought. It's as if the developer occasionally remembered they had to do something with it now and then, so they threw in a token room every so often where you have to turn into a cat for 5 seconds before doing platforming as a human.

Like most games in the genre, the combat is fairly simplistic, with your options being a melee attack and a bow, along with a roll that has a large number of immunity frames that's mandatory to use to avoid a lot of boss attacks. The combat, though, ended up being one of my biggest annoyances with the game through its poor design and inconsistencies. The melee attack consists of a simple three-hit combo, but the problem is each stage of the combo makes your character step forward slightly. The end result is numerous annoyingly positioned enemies either cause you to fall of a ledge into spikes (which kill you instantly), or cause you to step forward and take contact damage with the enemy you're hitting. 

Sometimes. Sometimes you take contact damage. That's half of the inconsistency in the combat, you sometimes take contact damage from touching enemies, Sometimes you don't! Whether or not you do is based on if the game feels like it. The other half is damage output from enemies and bosses, which has no consistency whatsoever. The same attack can do a massive variance of damage to the point where the damage values feel completely made up and just use a random number generator. As an example, one boss always starts by dropping a lightning bolt on you. Across dozens of observations, the exact same attack at random did barely a pixel of my life bar, a third of it, half of it, all but one pixel, and outright instantly killed me. Exact. Same. Attack. The *entire* game is like this--your life bar is just an imaginary number and the game decides you live or die from an attack based on completely arbitrary values.

Between all of these problems, I ended up just spamming the bow for the near entirety of my playtime. There's nothing tactical about this because you can't move and use the bow at the same time, but the bow was blatantly designed as the superior weapon in the game; the majority of passive equippables and required upgrades in the game buff the bow, the melee attack gets absolutely nothing unless you go out of your way to make it slightly less awful, and you can't do that until shortly before the final boss.

The boss fights themselves were at best acceptable, and at worst just downright annoying due to the combat mechanics. Your character cannot jump very high, and most bosses are the same height as you, with the end result being that if they pin you in a corner you WILL take contact damage trying to escape. Rolling is less useful as half the bosses have erratic movement such that rolling will cause you to take damage regardless. Overall, due to the fact you don't get any meaningful movement enhancing upgrades in the game and no alternatives or real upgrades to your attacks, the boss fights are pretty forgettable HP sponges where you spam the bow until they die.

Except they, for some reason, gave all the bosses special drops if you can beat them without taking damage. Half of these are items you can buy from a shopkeeper slightly later in the game, giving you a small power boost earlier than expected. The other half are exclusive items that are hilariously gamebreaking, capable of tearing through 30-50% of a boss's life in one use (and you get up to 2 uses of each gamebreaker item). The funny thing is all the bosses kill you instantly on Insane difficulty, forcing you to beat them hitless, giving you guaranteed access to all these gamebreaking items that let you crush the bosses without challenge. If the combat and movement systems were good in the game I'd accuse this of being cheesy and lame, but the bosses feel like such a waste of time that I fully advocate cheesing them. 

I've never played the other games in the series, and that isn't a problem with regards to the story and characters because the game has basically no story or characters. There's an evil curse, you need to cleanse it. End of story. There's like five characters you meet a single time, trust you immediately, and either tell you completely obvious observations about the game world (everybody is dead or a ghost? Wow couldn't have figured that out based on the ominous music and all the ghosts I've killed so far) or just hand you a key item. Only one of these characters even has a name, which just feels weirder. There's a few other completely worthless NPCs who say equally useless statements like "I'm scared" that don't add anything. 

And, finally, the game is short. That's probably one of the biggest upsides to the game, in that despite its stockpile of annoyances that incited me to make a review in the first place, it didn't last long enough to make me actually hate the game. It's barely 4 hours long, and that's on a first playthrough that got the true ending, all upgrades, and full map exploration. You can casually speedrun the game in under 40 minutes once you know where to go. Momo4 at its core being a short game is also the root cause of other problems, like how few upgrades the game has. Can't pace those well when you can beat the game blind in a single sitting.

Overall it's not offensively bad, not unplayable, is acceptably fun, but the problems with combat, lack of upgrades, dull exploration, and forgettable boss fights really dragged down my opinion of the game. But the game is often cheap on sale so it's still decent for a couple bucks.

88266999.review:
You've got to be careful. Start combining reveries with moonlight, and you're only a step or two from smoking clove cigarettes in a graveyard while writing free-verse poems about autumn.

Well, they don't go that far, but for something with such a cutesy look it does manage to create a surprisingly dark and somber mood. Between the falling leaves and misty forests, the shadowy towns and cathedrals, and the ominous red moon overhead--that's never a good sign--there's an awful lot of atmosphere for such a humble-looking little game.

Even more so than 3000th Duel this one really stress tests the fundamental strength of the metroidvania genre. How many load-bearing elements can you remove from a game like this while still retaining structural integrity?  Turns out, quite a few.

Who needs endless farming and complex crafting systems, zillions of spells and items or a HD graphical sheen? Just hand me some intuitive controls, nice animations, moody atmosphere, melancholy music and a map to fill in, and apparently I'm good.

The backgrounds in particular really stand out here. Not only do they look good for their style in a superficial sense, but there's also a real unifying artistry that helps them punch well above their graphical weight. You get the impression that the authors have a solid picture in their heads of this strange world of theirs. It comes across in the coherence of whole aesthetic, as well as the eccentric little touches--the cats, the the ringing bell save points, etc.--that combine to lend extra character.

I've heard people use the term "souls-like" to describe the combat, although in this case all that really means is that you have dodge sometimes and maybe think a little bit before swinging your weapon. 

Oh, that weapon, by the way? If I understand it right, it's some kind of magical leaf, which I've gotta say is definitely a first.

Yeah, don't ask me why that is. I guess this game doesn't require a whole lot of explanation, which is a good thing since they don't really give you any. Like everything else here, the story is pretty minimal.  You're some kind of magic nun or something who shows up in a cursed land to cleanse it of evil by swatting the dark queen with her killer leaf, and, uh, that's about all I got. 

But hey, just goes to show that it doesn't always take a lot.  A tightly-made little game with a strong basic design and a bit of creativity and some signature flair can have an outsized impact.

If you're interested in a nice metroidvania-style sojourn in a well-crafted setting--and who wouldn't be?--you'll probably walk away happy from this one despite their best efforts to the contrary.


You can find more indie game reviews at [url=https://oddlittlegames.com] oddlittlegames.com [/url] or visit my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/34514756/] curator page. [/url]  Thanks, and enjoy!

88264569.review:
Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight (Aka Momodora 4) is the 4th of the Momodora series.

The game is basically the same as Momodora 3 but with quite a lot of graphical updates as well as coding upgrades. The biggest visual change is the protagonist grew to 2.5 tiles height, far higher than the 1.5 tile of Momodora 1 and 1 tile height of Momodora 2 & 3. But the basic engine of the game seems to be the same as Momodora 3 (& 2).

The changes are, there's 2 playable forms of Kaho in this game, the human form (2.5 tile height) and the Kitty form (1 tile height). This enable certain hidden and secret area that are only reachable by the kitty form and certain places that can only be access by human form.

The basic battle is almost the same as Momodora 2&3, with a few changes. They've restored air dashing and double jump to the game. They've added an equipment table to the game, so we can now equip the items we found in game. 

The coding improvements also allowed certain graphic layout to be possible, making the game more beautiful than the previous series.

As for the story, it's certainly an upgrade compared to the previous series. Both story and story telling shows huge improvements. But still, not up to the professional standard yet. Just enough to keep the plot intact. They've tried to put some meaning to the previous series in this one. Adding Eri (from Momodora 2) suggesting Momodora 4 is from a timeline before Momodora 2. Kaho herself made an appearance in Momodora 3 as a NPC, so this is somewhere after Momodora 3. But still... it doesn't really matter as even when they tried to link the time line, the story isn't related and player will not miss a thing if they didn't play the other series.

Like Momodora 3, this one here has multiple ending. As well as secret areas and hidden items to collect. So completionist can have their fun doing the collection hunt.

From Momodora 1 to 4 we can see the slow improvements of the games as it gets better and better. Hopefully one day, they will be able to produce some professional ones as Momodora 4 is almost there.

For those who stick with the series since 1, of course you won't want to miss out this one.
For those who are new to the Momodora series, you can play this one without playing the others. But still, give the others a try, 1 & 2 are free on their website.

I feel bad because overall I liked this game and enjoyed the experience, but don't think I could recommend it for most people if it was any more than the current four bucks.

Pros - 
+ Lovely music
+ Cute art style and character design
+ Quite good atmosphere most of the time
+ Bosses are fun 

Cons - 
- pretty sluggish gameplay until you get some upgrades, that you dont get until like a third of the way through the game, which really doesnt take that long because...
- The game is really short, like I didn't complete the game or anything, but I took my time, got most of the stuff and got the true ending and it took less than five hours
- Enemy scaling is really off. you see the same witch enemy after leaving the tutorial area (which by the way, the tutorial consists of mostly enemies that inflict poison on you) is seen literally throughout the game and you see one just before the final boss. The game felt pretty unfair until I got some upgrades, then it just felt pretty easy.
- The game doesn't seem designed around only having manual saves at certain locations. With most traps or pits in the game instantly killing you, exploring is really stressful as any character interactions, items you picked up, map you uncovered, etc. is lost if you die and you have to do them all over again. I came back to the game after several months, beat a boss, and came across a lake. I proceed to go "huh, is there swimming in this game?", walked in, fell through, and died instantly and had to do the boss all over again.

Also, why does the weapon upgrade that is required to get the true ending just kinda slapped in a well with no mention by anyone whatsoever and no buildup?[/spoiler]
- The MC's goddamn idle yawning animation. Don't get me wrong, it's cute, but it really needs to be disabled for a little after boss/story segments. Nothing kills atmosphere like narrowly defeating someone you are meant to feel bad for fighting, seeing the person you killed fade away, not realize you have control again and the MC just step back and yawn like "what? that's it?" like, what is your character again? 

Ok so overall, I'd say the art, music, characters, and world of Momodora are wonderful, but from a mechanics and story standpoint the game falls really flat for me. If you enjoy metroidvanias and want a game to chill with for an afternoon, you might like the game, but I really wouldn't recommend it beyond that

86593973.review:
Aloha, this is my review of Momodora, a side-scrolling Metroidvania platform RPG where you play as a white robed priest named Kaho and use the most unlikely of weapons [a maple leaf! oh Canada!] to fight through hordes of monsters and bosses and stop the queen's curse from corrupting the land. If you liked Minoria, then consider getting this game. If you haven't played either, then I recommend Minoria as being the better of the two.

The Good: Pixel graphics and music are great, the controls are tight and responsive, the fantasy setting is imaginative too. The game is quite brief [my first run lasted 4 Hours 20 minutes], but there is new game+ and other challenge modes to satisfy even the most soul's-thirsty masochist.

The Bad: low monster variety, combat is simplistic [dodge, stunlock, kill], the minimalist story that would make Dark Souls seem overly detailed, characters were forgettable.

The Ugly: the challenge modes are linked to the steam achievements [even no deaths], so don't expect to 100% this game.

86189017.review:
After finally Perfecting the game (100% achievements), I had better write a review. 

This is one of my absolute favorite games and I can't recommend it enough. I don't know if everyone will get the special feeling I do from this game, but even if you have a more casual interest I think you'll enjoy it.  It's cute, short, and made very well. To me, the game is basically perfect and I have no complaints whatsoever. It's one of the first games I've speedran and it's the first real game I've Perfected.

If I look past the emotional attachment I've gained for Momodora over the years I still think it's a beautiful game. The traversal is fun. You get a variety of skills and powerups in Metroidvania fashion (more Castlevania than Metroid) and several of them affect how fast you can move as well as allowing you to explore and progress. The combat is simple and even trivialized by some of the powerful items, but the difficulty levels are very well tuned so you can have the challenge you want. The simplicity is redeemed by being polished to very satisfying levels. The art, sound design and music are fantastic. It succeeds at being both very cute and somber. The writing for the story, lore and characters walks the line of telling you just enough to have a solid foundation while leaving a lot up to the interpretation of the player. As you can tell, every aspect of the game follows the trend: less is more. It works because it's so cohesive and polished. It could feel empty or basic, but the mood is just right and you'll become much more invested than you would expect.

My save files suggest that you can expect 5-6 hours from the game at minimum, which is already worth the price tag. The game doesn't feel short. I think it's very replayable (and speedrunnable!) and you could get a LOT more out of it.

Shout out to halfcoordinated! Life is both a gift and a challenge.

85577102.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Momodora: Reverie Under the Moonlight (RUtM) is a metroidvania (2D platformer with sprawling map that encourages backtracking once your character earns powerups) where you play as Kaho, a priestess tasked with saving her land from a curse. You traverse various castle grounds in search of the queen's help, wielding your magical leaf and bow, gaining magical items and meeting characters along the way. The game is the fourth in a series, although you don't have to have played the previous games to understand this one.


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
While your main weapon (a magic leaf) stays the same throughout, so much of the game is about smooth and satisfying combat. Each encounter is an awesome acrobatic romp, as you vanquish evil with well timed dodgerolls, quickly fired arrows and a good whack of your leaf. 

After about an hour on "normal" mode, I played the rest of the game on "hard" mode, which was a good balance between challenge and stress. Most situations could be navigated through with a little determination and careful planning, and the variation in magical objects and loadout to use definitely added to the fun. When the difficulty ramped up with the boss fights, you were challenged to understand their patterns and attack accordingly. At most moments I felt powerful and threatened at the same time, which was an amazing balance. Again, I cannot understate how smoothly the combat plays. The only critique I have of this aspect of the game was that [i]sometimes[/i] the hitboxes felt a millimeter or two off, but for the most part they were fine.

The enemies and bosses varied in interesting ways, and the exploration of each map area was interesting as well. 

It should be said that the game is shorter than your average metroidvania. I was surprised to check my map after a few hours and see that I had already covered 40% of it. That said, it doesn't really detract from the quality of the game - and the calls to replay it on "insane" mode (with only 1 hp) or with a pacifist run, speak louder than most games given the enjoyability of the combat and movement.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story reminds me of Dark Souls (doesn't everything?). The characters don't say much, although they do say enough for you to connect with the overall downtrodden and derelict mood of the game. The mood and exposition are compelling and they do drive the player forward through twists and turns, which end up jam-packed in this short game. Like Dark Souls, much of the lore is stored in item descriptions, for those who are interested. 

The characters are interesting, though this aspect does suffer slightly for its preoccupation with an anime girl aesthetic. For instance, it is a little embarrassing or distracting when the chest of one of the bosses reacts to the swipes of your leaf. But for the most part the anime girl aesthetic isn't foregrounded, and there is also something to be said for having a cast of interesting female characters who mostly aren't sexualized. 

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The pixelated art of this game is beautiful. It isn't exquisitely detailed, but it is worth looking at and is distinct all the same. Each section of the map was a vibrant (or deliberately not vibrant) area that I looked forward to exploring.

The only critique of this aspect comes along with the previously mentioned critique, there is occasional unnecessary sexualization of the cast of female characters, but, again, this isn't too significant, I would say. 

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The audio here is the extravagant seal on this 16 bit love letter. All of the sound effects are delightful saw waves and square waves. And the background tracks for each boss battle and map area, while not staying in the 16 bit style, are [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CXGdHu1b1fg]evocative and encompassing[/url]. 

[h1]Technical & Other[/h1]
It took a while to set up the proper resolution of the game, and occasionally the were issues with audio, but these issues weren't significant.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
Momodora: RUtM is a fun little metroidvania. It is short, but a treat to play given its satisfying combat, and was only helped by its compelling story and characters. I urge you to play it and give some enemies a good 3 hit combo of the magic leaf.

85549549.review:
This game has some pretty big issues. I don't think it's worth the price tag, or the 9/10 on steam. 

pros:
- nice pixel art
- cool enemy designs
- a couple fun boss fights
- a few memorable ost's
- area aesthetics are pretty looking and distinct

cons:
- boring combat: devolves to just stunlocking regular enemies
- boring platforming, almost annoying: not helped by spikes and pits which can instantly kill you
- slow sense of progression which isn't helped by mandatory backtracking which makes the game a slog to get through
- story is confusing and uninteresting.
- the save system does not keep map exploration, therefore making it even more tedious to progress
- enemy damage is way too high (a lot of regular enemies can 2 shot you)
- boss and enemy telegraphs are sometimes unreasonably short to react to (resulting in cheap hits which shred half your health)
- when they are telegraphed, they're sometimes lazily done with a white circle which indicates multiple different attacks
- a couple bosses have way too much health making it an unfair and boring endurance fight considering how much damage they do
- enemy variation is sparse and doesn't make areas seem unique and fun to progress through
- overpriced for the value you get from it (4 hours of subpar gameplay)

If you're looking for a good metroidvania for a similar price, I suggest checking out either Hollow Knight or Ori 2.

84258023.review:
I have never been a fan of metroidvanias, I either find the maps too overwhelmingly big, get frustrated over their difficulty or simply leave due to them being too long and me losing interest (which happened recently when I played hollow knight). But with Momodora: Reverie Under The Moonlight, I didn't have any issues replaying it after trying it a few years back and getting most of the achievements.

The game is short enough to never lose my interest, the visuals are beautiful, the difficulty is challenging but once you learn the boss patterns, its easy to deal with them. The map is small enough to never overwhelm the player, same with items, collectibles and achievements, there are never enough of these to a point where it gets overwhelming, but there was enough to get me to play 10 hours. This allows the player to feel like their progress is actually meaningful and motivates them to keep playing even after they completed the game.

In my case, I didn't do more playthroughs nor got the harder achievements, but I did get my map to 100% and got all the collectibles, which is something I usually dont do in most of the games I play.

If I had to highlight some negative aspects: I'd say the resolution of the game in windowed felt too small, a few platforming sections felt a bit unfair, if you died after a boss and didn't save, you had to beat it again, the location of some collectibles felt forced, some of them were behind invisible walls that the player had no way to notice other than looking at guides. And last, there was this elevator you could trigger by accident that didn't allow you to leave and took forever to stop, but other than this, the game was great.

tl;dr: Even if you are not a fan of metroidvanias, you should give this game a chance, its a fun and short platformer that features great visuals, its challening, fairly easy to 100% and never gets boring.

I found the environmental visuals and the level design in the game to be pretty good, and I like a lot of the enemy designs too. There's something oddly captivating about one boss in particular, Lubella, that really managed to draw me in. The addition of the [spoiler]cat sphere, allowing the player to transform into a cat[/spoiler] was great way to switch things up a little bit and everything felt really smooth and good playing that way. Generally the game controlled pretty well, and the oomph behind your hits is satisfying, but I did feel the melee combat could be a touch clunky at times with often accidentally bumping into enemies and taking damage while stepping forward to attack.
